name: The Wolf Among Us
description: From the makers of the 2012 Game of the Year: The Walking Dead, comes a gritty, violent and mature thriller based on the award-winning Fables comic books (DC Comics/Vertigo). As Bigby Wolf - THE big bad wolf - you will discover that a brutal, bloody murder is just a taste of things to come in a game series where your every decision can...

reviews.review_text: One of the best story games in Steam. It was so good my friends sat around the computer watching me play it. It was like watching a really good movie except you are playing it. The story is so well done that you cannot help but to be engrossed in it. The visuals are amazing if you like a comic books which I do!! Some games have that cheesy voice acting but this game was top notch. It had just the right amount of everything for everybody. Script, score ... the whole shabang! INCREDIBLE!! You will be missing out on one fine game if you have not played it. Wicked!!

Pros: -Realistic and likeable characters. -Great voice acting,you feel the emotion through their voices. -Great music,i fell in love with the soundtrack.  -Cool extras,tons of info in the book of Fables. -Mature,there's alot of violence and a little nudity. -Great graphics,its like im playing a noir comic.  -I'll definitely play Season 2 if they make it.  Cons: -Very linear with little variation and replayability.  -Ending,while not bad it leaves you with a cliffhanger. -Bug that makes your choices unusable until you restart the chapter.  Verdict A solid 8 if you haven't played the game yet go ahead and grab it,sale or no sale its worth your time.
Superb example of Telltale's storytelling

New York City in the 1980s was a miserable place, and from the first few moments of The Wolf Among Us you can feel it. Even worse than the sticky heat of the city is the plight of the Fables, famous characters that appear in stories like Snow White or The Legend of Sleepy Hollow, exiled from their Homeland and forced to live among human 'mundies'. Placing storybook characters in a modern city is a neat enough premise, but it's the simple and elegant investigative storytelling that makes the five-part series a joy to explore.  It's up to you playing as Bigby Wolf to keep the Fables from being discovered, and to keep them from hurting themselves too much. The former Big Bad Wolf, Sherriff Bigby embodies the noir detective with a dark past and a heart of gold, but his character fortunately never strays too far into hard-boiled cliche. Well, he does drink quite a bit, and smokes cigarettes constantly, true to type but he's got one of the Three Pigs sleeping at his apartment, which isn't. And when the pig calls Bigby out on his lone wolf demeanor, it's extremely apt.  The Wolf Among Us is a highly cinematic point-and-click adventure that consists mostly of interactive cutscenes. When you interrogate people, you have a limited time to choose between 3 dialogue options; if you let the time run out, you stay silent and let the other character continue talking. How you go about examining crime scenes and how you treat other characters effects how the story plays out. If you threaten a character, they will remember it and treat you differently next time they see you. Sort of like a choose-your-own-adventure book.  Even if you use a controller, your interface is a cursor that moves around the screen and lets you interact with people and objects, examine clues, and fight. Like everything else, the combat is cinematic. Tap a certain button or click an object in time and watch the cutscene, or get your face knocked in.   At first glance, the graphics for The Walking Dead and Wolf Among Us are almost identical, but this is actually where the two games start to differentiate themselves. Telltale's The Walking Dead seems to have drawn more inspiration from the show than the comic. The slightly softer shading and muted tones make it the more 'realistic' looking of the two; while The Wolf Among Us has much heavier cel shading and highly saturated colors that make it look like a hand-drawn comic. This isn't to say that the graphics are anything short of amazing- they really capture the gritty comic book atmosphere without being overly cartoony- it looks like a living, breathing comic book. Speaking as someone who normally hates motion comics, Telltale has set a new standard for comic book adaptations.  If you're not a big reader, you won't need you to run out and read every issue of Fables you can get your hands on before playing Wolf Among Us- they make it as user friendly as possible. For the uninitiated, Telltale has included the Book of Fables- every time you come across a new character or concept, an entry is added in the Book of Fables that fills you in on their backstory in the Fables universe. Wolf Among Us has Bill Willingham's seal of approval on it to be part of the Fable's Universe. So if you're already an avid reader, there you go.  For all the Fables fans, there's obviously a lot of familiar territory here. 'Faith' is similar to the very first Fables arc where Bigby Wolf and Snow White solve Rose Red's murder- a great hard-boiled detective story where they piece together clues and interrogate fantastic characters in order to get to the bottom of a grisly mystery. Keep in mind that The Wolf Among Us takes place twenty years before the first Fables story, so all of our key players are a little rough around the edges. Snow White is only Ichabod Crane's assistant, and she isn't sure if she's cut out to be a public servant. Depending on the choices you make as Bigby, you can be gruff-but-well-meaning, or you can smash and intimidate your way through your leads, not caring where the collateral damage leads you.  As I always do with multiple choice games, I had to do two run-throughs where I take opposing paths. Each episode takes about 2-3 hours to run through, but once you take your first bite into the story, you're hooked. Episodes of The Wolf Among Us end with a 'to be continued' trailer just like The Walking Dead, and I can already see how both of my save files are playing out differently- it was like I was watching two completely different trailers. Telltale has perfected their episodic formula.  There's a lot in The Wolf Among Us for Fables fans to get excited about. And if you're new to the series, it's just as good an introduction as reading the first tradeback. I enjoyed the game so much that I did two run-throughs one after another. Either way, play The Wolf Among Us. You won't regret it.

Great story game from TTG  PROS +Epic setting based on great comics +SUPERB main hero +SUPERB characters +Storyline is great +Action scenes is epic +Tons of Humor  CONS -Second season still not announced  Great game with epic storyline and tons of fun,you should play it!

I didn't know how great this game was, till I had a friend gift it to me. At first, I didn't know if I would find this to be my kind of story but that instantly dissolved away after I finished the first episode. It feels like I really missed out on a great story this whole time because of the title. Not really a big werewolf fan but learning that this game has other magical/fairytale characters, I was hooked right away. The imagery is beautiful and well done. The music is haunting, relaxing, and captivating. This is definitely a game that no one could ever forget or simply put down.
At least my grandchildren will enjoy a 15% discount to the sequel.

If you liked Season One of The Walking Dead from Telltale Games, you should like this too. I don't think it's quite as good as that, but it's still a fun and engrossing story. Filled with great characters and memorable set pieces, I definitely give this a thumbs up.  But it seems there are a million reviews all stating how great the story is an everything, so I'm going to nitpick a few things that will hopefully prove more informative.  I would call this a choose your own adventure game opposed to a point and click game. You basically enjoy the story and make decisions along the way. Each chapter has one or two 'action' set pieces that consist of QTEs that I'm not even sure if you can fail. The decisions are important though. Some are clearly favored to one perspective while others are more ambiguous as to their outcome. Yet others are just 'eff you, I'm the Big Bad Wolf.' Some decisions will lock you out of entire areas to investigate. There is an inventory, yet it's pointless, you never have to combine items or use the right item on the right background object. There really aren't any puzzles to solve. So like I said, it's more a book than a game, even though it's a damn fine one at that.  I also didn't feel like the story lived up to the conclusion of the first episode. The rest of the episodes are good, but they never reach that 'holy s--t!!' moment at the end of the episode one. The season does end with a rather spectacular action sequence, but then the ensuing conversations and final decision kind of drag on, losing that intensity.  But again, just nitpicking. You should definitely check it out for yourself.

After finishing The Wolf Among Us i decided that Telltale Games is definitely the King of point and click adventure games.  The Wolf Among Us reveals us the magical world of Fables, a world entirely different of the one we  mundies  think we're living in. A world where pigs can smoke, and the wolf hunts the Huntsman. Based on the Fables comic books, the game depicts a series of crimes committed in Fabletown, which you, as sheriff Bigby aka The Big Bad Wolf must solve. The story is just great, intriguing and with a lot of twists, there is no doubt about it, and the fact that you're to choose what and when happens just makes it greater, even if this does not apply for all choices made during the game. The voice acting is marvelous and the artwork is spectacular. The facial expressions are also much more realistic than in TWD or any other Telltale game so far.  Even in a positive review, I usually try to cover also the negative sides of a game, but this time Telltale guys gave me no chance for it. There is nothing i didn't like, nothing that didn't feel appropriate, not a single aspect i could complain with. The Wolf Among Us turned out to be exactly what i expected it to be - my GOTY of 2014 for point-and-click adventure games.

I like Tell Tale Games after playing 'Life is Strange'. And 'The Wolf Among Us' is the one of the best Tell Tale Games i ever played too. This game talking about many fable stories in modern town now.  The Thriller and mystery athmosphere makes this game so great .
I hope there will be season 2 of this game .Telltale know how to tell a tale. 10/10 I want more !!!

Pros:     Strong narrative and intriguing story keeps you curious and hooked from start to the end.    You freely characterize 'Bigby' a.k.a. 'Big Bad Wolf' into a good and caring detective or a savage and cruel wolf.    Dark, gloomy atmosphere and true detective-noir tale.    Nearly all decisions are significant and have impact on game.    Gorgeus art style and music.    Familiar characters from classic fables such as The Big Bad Wolf, Woodsman, Snow White, Bloody Mary, Beauty and Beast.    Best and favorite Telltale game for me.       Cons:      It lasts only ten hours.    The wait for second season.     A+

The Wolf Among US  Graphics 7.5 of 10 The Graphics are very stylish, kind of Neo-Noir with a little take on the 80ies fashion and style. Lots of bright flashing colors, neon colors all done in comic style.  Gameplay 7.5 of 10 It's a classic point-and-click game with some quick time events. But it's a tad short. I finished the game in about 8.5 hours.  Story 8 of 10 You play as Bigby Woolf aka the big bad wolf and uncover the secret of a series of grisly murders in Fabletown. Fabletown is the hideout of the fairytale characters in the 'real „world .But the real world made some of them turn to shady business or else .You always have to question their motives. And you make decisions and they matter...sort of .Without spoiling too much, but the plot is excellent.  It's an excellent story with really likeable characters, especially Bigby.It has some really hilarious moments, but at other times it's really grim and dark. Overall I would generally recommend this game to all mature gamers, because it contains strong language and blood and gore.

In The Wolf Among Us you play as Bigby Wolf, a sheriff operating in a world inhabited by characters from fariy tales. Although this may at first sound childish (assuming you’re not a fan of the comics on which it is based), the game is actually very dark and violent as it paints these well-known characters in a very different light.   Best described as an interactive story, you point and click your way through various scenes as you attempt to unfold the mystery at hand. You will often be forced to choose from various dialogue options, allowing you to paint yourself in whatever light you desire and eliciting different reactions from the NPCs.   The storyline is absolutely captivating and really keeps you guessing, its never boring or predictable. Each chapter is fantastic, full of intrigue and mystery, and I had a very difficult time staying patient in between releases.   The final episode is extremely satisfying while also leaving you craving more. I absolutely cannot wait for the next season, will be an instant buy for me.   This is the game that made me fall in love with Telltale's ability to captivate with their wonderful storytelling, and caused me to go from someone who was very skeptical of this genre of game to being a huge fan.

Episode 1 - Faith  A truly great game by its own that doesn't live in the shadows of The Walking Dead. In fact, in certain aspects of the game such as texture quality and the weight of the choices you make this first episode is actually better than the first episode of TWD.  dat ending *mindblown*, I want episode 2!!!

I honestly wasn't expecting a whole lot, mainly because the idea behind 'Point and Click' seemed unappealing to me at first. It went on sale, so I figured why not? Only an hour or so in and I'm already thoroughly enjoying it, and I can't wait to see what's in store for the upcoming episodes.

Like wow just wow, definately a must play for those that love a good story and or detective games and murder mysteries. Definately another solid telltale game. :)

Telltale did another great job with Wolf Among Us  Based on the Vertigo HQ, the story follow bigby wolf, the sheriff of fabletown, a town where fable characters lives and is located in New York City.  A game full of quick time events, action, crime and blood, recommended  11/10

Very solid detective game. Very rare product of episodic released content. Point & Click polished to perfection. I never read the comic books (visual novels), but TellTale went a long way from their first games with 'The Wolf Among Us'.    This game is a hope for me for detectives as a genre in video games will stand on thier own terms on the scene. There is a big audience for gritty noir-like, or neo-noir narrative. A strong player agency illusion is succesfully created. Smart gamifying props 'Mr. John noticed that' after answering his question does a lot. Small elements made this game appropriate for the wide audience.    Plainly digressing - this isn't as big and big buget as L.A. Noire.  It's confusing from the prologue (no context without reading the source material), some answers are decorative. But the whole picture is far too gorgeous to not want a continuation.    Thank you for not leaving this on a cliffhanger like most episodic games/movies do. That big user rating is a token of respect for that attitude TellTale Games.
This game is the polar opposite of The Walking Dead in the sense that you won't have to take a cry break every 10 minutes.
A Telltale game living up to Asura's Wrath QTE drama. Much praise.
All the soul The Walking Dead Season 2 lacked seems to have been poured straight into The Wolf Among Us.

Fabolous graphic! Good fantasy noir story, very unique and original. Same gameplay as The Walking dead. Stay away if you don't like quick time events, there're a lot of them! But The story is very catching! Good Beginning for me!

Worth every penny, even in full price. If you're questioning if you should buy it on discount, just do it.  One of the best story-driven games I have ever played. Congratulations to Telltale on their fantastic work. I finished this game a year and a half ago and I remain amazed.

The Wolf Among Us, possibly the best Telltale game let alone the best story in a mystery game ever.  Character Depth: Bigby is more compelling than Lee, yes I said it. This guy had so much depth. He's the sheriff a symbol of good and authority but yet his fable (The Big Bad Wolf) Stands for destruction and devestation. That mix makes the ultimate character.  Unlike the walking dead the characters you meet are in real problems like debt. They have to worry about a shady employer than a zombie. When you interact with them you feel for them, you want them to be happy. In the Walking Dead you know its a ♥♥♥♥ world all around you and you try to make the best out of it but in the wolf among us you really feel they can make it in this world and they deserve a happy life. I can tell you that every character in this game has a purpose and a meaning. Whether you hate em or love em you'll know em.  Choices: The Wolf Among us choices are the best. Even though they may come in a loop and you really can't decide what happens in the situation you. The best part about the choices in this game is tied with your character, Bigby. You can either be the 'Big Bad Wolf' For an evil playthrough and shock terror into your allies and enemies like your fable is. Or you can be the good guy, try to show fabletown that your different and here to help for a good playthrough. I'll tell you first hand when you show your good theres no better feeling.  Side Note to TT: One thing I have a beef with in TT games is romance, call me sappy but they bring it on themselves. In the wolf among us and several other TT games they set you up for love interests, maybe multiples. There is never an option to expand on those feelings for a character. They even blatenly point out that a character likes another or they interact in a certain way indicating that they like eachother but there isn't an option to even give em an affectionate hug or kiss. I think in future TT games there should be more options to have relationships.  Story: This story had me tossing and turning in my sleep. I would only play an episode a night because I didn't want it to be over. Every night after I played the episode and went to bed it would pop up in my dreams. It was THAT good. Your a tough guy but your in a situation where you just might not be able to muscle your way out of a situation and you feel helpless!   In all get this game and you'll love it, if you don't you might just save yourself an itch that can't be scratched cuz once this game is over you'll just be wanting more.
I haven't posted a review. But my opinion? I loved it. I hope they'll make a sequel to this.

This game is supposed to be a prequel to a comic book series called Fables. It is about all sorts of fairy tale characters we know (e.g. Red Riding Hood, Beauty and Beast) who live among us as they were forced to leave their home. In Fabletown (which is part of New York) they try to blend in with the humans (who they call 'mundies') and for those not having human form it proves to be difficult: an enchantment called 'glamour' is a must to change forms, otherwise they are sent to 'The Farm' which is not exactly a place any Fable wants to be.  The game takes place in the '80s and the player assumes the control of the Wolf from Red Riding Hood. Big Wolf - or Bigby - acts as the Sheriff of Fabletown and is set out to solve a crime that ended in the death of one of the Fables. He is aided by Snow White and other fairy tale / folklore characters we may or may not recognise.  Now, if you have already played a Telltale adventure game Wolf Among Us will be familiar to you:  --- there are a relatively few places where objects can be picked up or interacted with (we have the option to investigate our surroundings while the rest of the game gives us a mainly film-like experience with lots of cutscenes and dialogues) --- your inventory does not really get full of items and if an item can be used with another one in the environment the game tells you that  --- there are lots of characters to speak with and during conversations you have a limited time to pick an answer - these affect the relationship you have with these people and a choice can often have dire consequences --- due to the availability of choices a 2nd or even a 3rd walkthrough can easily yield you new results (the changes can even affect the end game) --- during action sequences quick-time-events are common but the pop-up buttons are easy to hit - this is not a difficult game (the main idea here is the immersion)  Wolf Among Us sports an interesting story and it entertains you from start to finish while you try to find the killer of Fabletown. Since prior to this I played the Walking Dead series I can make a comparison between the two: Wolf has more action sequences and while there's drama it certainly is less emotional. Oh, and make no mistake: just because it is about fairy tale characters gore and violence (along with cursing) is common.  For fans of Telltale adventure games this is a recommended title - for newcomers it's also worth checking.
I enjoyed myself playing this game. I got hooked and beat it fast lol Cannot wait for more stories to come!!!! TRY IT :) The story line was good.

The Wolf Among Us is a game I never really expected much from, but was completely blown away. I will even admittedly say that I may have even enjoyed this series more than TellTale's famous The Walking Dead series.  --Final thoughts at the bottom--   Gameplay  The game play is reminiscent to TellTales other adventure games. You progress through the story by investigating areas to find useful information or a way of proceding to the next area. Their is no complex puzzles or anything to get you stuck as the game is heavily story related so it tries to keep you progressing.   Most of the gameplay is about carefully choosing your response to conversations or story event where you must choose between doing X or doing Y. Quicktime events fill in alot of the action parts and add to the intensity.   Graphics  The cell shaded art style fits perfectly into this world they have created. The characters are well drawn and animated, some feel very recognizable. The facial movements and body movements look good, however some people still seem to walk like they have a stick up their butt(This is an issue I have with all TellTale games).   The world they have created sets the perfect setting for how the story takes place. The amount of detail they went into on some of the level design is very well done, even in places you arent around for very long. Its nice to see them still put the detail in to make this feel like a live breathing world.   Audio  The sound is done very well in The Wolf Among Us. The background noise and ambience was well done. The music is superb for the style they are going for in this game. The theme song kinda reminds me of Farcry 3: Blood Dragon music. The ingame music was very good at setting the mood for the events happening as well as for the areas you were exploring.  The voice over work is phenomenal and is what brings this story to life. The voices chosen for each character fit their rolls perfectly. Not once did I hear any voice that I thought to myself 'that doesn't fit'. The emotions are portrayed very well through their voices and sucks the player into the story. Top notch voice acting all around.   Story  The story is where this game really shines. I must admit I was never really interested in this game, nor did I really here to much about it, other than 'Its good'. So I went in knowing nothing about the plot or anything. Wow was I blown away by what I experienced.  It takes place in a place known as 'Fabletown' which is a small community of fables built on the outskirts of a real world city(I believe its New York). This community is build up of Fables who have left 'The woodlands' and have moved into city to live in a real society. However when murders start happening, fabletown turns to terror.   You, Bigby Wolf, AKA the big bad wolf, being the sheriff must hunt down and get to the bottom of whoever is behind it. One way or Another. This is The Wolf Among Us's biggest feature. The choices. Every choice you make in this game effects the story severely, even more than TellTales other games. In the walking dead when you madea choice it always felt like no matter what you did it would still end up being the same result, however the wolf among us does the opposite. Every choice effects how people in fabletown view you, which in turn effects trust, reliability, story arc changes and much more. You begin to really care about the characters. You begin to take more time with decisions, knowing that what you do could make characters love or hate you and this could effect how useful they are to you down the line.   The story progresses very fluently and keeps you wanting to know more. Their are loads of plot twists that will keep your mind bumbling for more answers. Just when you think you got it figured out, *BAM!!* plot twist. my only complaint about the story was that it was rather short, I played through all 5 episodes in less than 8hrs.   Final thoughts  After going into this game knowing nothing about it other than 'its good', I must say I was blown away by the world they created, and The story had me hooked and thinking about it even when I wasnt playing. The way this game makes you care for its characters is incredible and the obsolutely phenomenal voice over work brings them to life with a voice. The animation and level design is gorgeously done in TellTale's signature cell shaded art and everything plays very smooth with a smooth looking framerate, which is I know alot of problem had with the first season of the walking dead.   If you are looking for a game with a unique world and setting, with an amazing story. Then you will love the Wolf Among Us. If you are on the fence about this game, its definetly worth the buy. For a game I wasnt expecting much out of, I must say I think this may be my favourite game created by TellTale(Yes even better than the walking dead).

Yet another hit from Telltale games. A series that actually made me venture out and read the material it's based on, Fables, due to how heavily invested I got with their characters. Do not hesitate on picking this up if you're interested.

This game is astounding in it's presentation, storytelling and overall production. Telltale Games IMO has become the masters of adventure games and interactive storytelling. This is a high tech 'choose your own adventure' story book.   The story itself was gripping. The acting was very good. The cinematic feel to it was very engaging. I haven't taken in an adventure game so good since the Walking Dead series or even Grimm Fandango. Trust me, for the price you will get far more entertainment value than any movie in theaters. Plus no crying babies, overpriced popcorn and you can sip all the Scotch you want.

♥♥♥♥ing amazing, if you're after a good, dark story with tough decision making this is for you. Don't let the QTEs throw you, TWAU and other TellTale games are the few cases where QTEs work, since they're core gameplay and great fun.  Well? ♥♥♥♥ing buy it already. 9.5/10

Another TellTale masterpiece in interactive narrative with great characters.   Pros:  - Story. A deadly mystery that delves deeply in Fables (fairy tale) lore and packs a substantial amounts of twists  - Characters! Bigby, Snow, Crane or Georgie, each is finely crafted with stellar voice acting  - voice acting!!   - soundtrack. very atmospheric  - perfect TellTale style choices  - easy on your machine, still looks good and is immersive  - sets are designed with love and care  - it gets pretty brutal  - I love the opening  Cons:  - not a game per se. more of an interactive TV series  - some might be turned off by the more graphic and explicit nature of The Wolf Among Us. tread with care if sexual or overly violent content offends or disgusts you  - absolutely uninspired 'achievements' ... rather wish they skip that.  Verdict:  A must have for fans of the Fable comics, and surely a great addition to anyone's library. The Wolf Among Us delivers a mature crime drama with supernatural elements, sprinkled with some good old fashioned ultra violence. This is served with memorable characters, performances and development. Better than TV

First off, this game ruined my childhood. That said, I absolutely recommend it. Amazing story, art, music and voice acting. Telltale nailed it once again! You play as Bigby Wolf trying to solve what at first looked like a simple murder, and at the same time, trying to supress your brutal instincts (or not). Lots of unexpected events and tense moments, with a great Noire atmosphere. I will probably play it again from the start, this time being a total prick.  I really look forward to grabbing the graphic novels this game is based on...
I was suprised by how much I'm enjoying playing this game. Nice gritty and dark universe with a choice driven plot.
One of the best Point and Click games I have ever played, coming in closely behind Monkey Island. This along with Walking Dead Season 1 really raises the bar
Not as emotionally involving as Telltale's TWD but just as good. The whole noir vibe is fantastic.

Finally they made an interactive movie that's right up my alley.  Good story. great characters (thanks to comics creator Bill Willingham), excellent dialogues and voiceover, unique and colorful film noir atmosphere.   The Big Bad Wolf & Snow White are now my most favorite game couple since Guybrush & Elaine.  8/10 huff-puff smokes

Dear player: you are dumb.   You're such a socially inept nerd, you probably can't even interpret facial expressions or voice pitching. That's why we will inform you with those neat 'XYZ will remember that' boxes.   Also we really love to delude you into buying the thought that 'every decision can have enormous consequences', even though in the 9 hours you will play this game, there are only like 3 occasions were this statement would really be the case.   No matter what you do, the plot line will always head in the same direction, at the same speed. There's no branching path or shortcut at all. So even if you connect the clues the game gives you, you may wait a very long time till your ingame character does so. The choices you can make are once again very limited.  So much for rambling about the bad points. Now onto the good stuff, which imho fortunately outweighs everything mentioned previously.  The game is based on the DC Comic Series 'Fables'. Once you are into the game you immediately got that gritty noir vibe going. It's atmospheric, stylish and quite unique in the gaming sector. The cell-shading graphics fit that base very well. From what I can tell the voice acting also is very professional and completely flawless.   Even though the story tends to be stereotypical at times, the characters are believable in their own motivations and actions. There's no black and white run-of-the-mill evil villain to find here. It's almost like the story arc - just like the artstyle, the music and voice acting - is once more another plattform for the twisted and crazy, but often still very likeable characters to shine through.  I played through the complete game in about 9 hours and the standard price would be 22,99€ in Europe (Tier 1). That is a lot of value for your money, considering that this game feels more like watching an entire season of an interactive series then anything else.  Here you go. The 'Call of Duty' of adventure games. Just like Activision took the essence of action games and multiplied it by 10 for the sake of entertainment, while leaving out the more interesting aspects of gameplay, Telltale do the same thing in their own genre. It's extremely dialogue-heavy and entertaining, but if you're looking for interesting gameplay.. go look somewhere else.
Standard Telltale quality, perfect noire atmosphere and an exciting, stylish lead-in for the next seasons. Must have!
awesome story and great dialogue, heavy with the choices too.
furry simulator

Genre: Interactive Story - Fantasy/Film Noir A very good telltale game. It stands up to the Walking Dead and it had me enthralled from start to finish. Episodes will be staggered, on writing this there was only one released. It links to the Fable comics that I have briefly looked at before, and they seemed an interesting concept.

Oh. My. God. That was amazing! One of the best storytelling I have ever seen. And sooo much ending wow. I wish more games like this existed, some who give you freedom to choose, lets you do things like you want regarding on situation. Another great visual comic game by Telltale. As mentioned in my Walking Dead review, you need to be down for this level of (or lack of) gameplay, but assuming that...  Fabletown was a cool, grungy place to visit, and it was a refreshing change to play in a less well known universe. The main plot's investigation was an interesting way to use the Telltale engine. Kudos in particular to the excellent art direction and noir soundtrack. I'm going to be humming the prologue and intro tracks for months to come...  ...Hopefully Season Two will be around by then?

Pros:  -Engaging story (filled with suspense, twsits and excitement)..Kept me hooked one ep after the other. -Beautiful art style (very atmospheric) -Good voice acting  Cons:  -Not long anough -Needs deeper development on impact of choices and decisions  -Need to feel that my character isn't the only one actively deciding  -Clonky movement on PC WASD keys  My qualms with the game:  However halfway through, the options and what it actually 'means' and would it would lead to actually became quite obvious, thus lessening the fun and impact of deciding my actions. At one point I became quite frustrated since the game puts you in a position where you constantly have to be understanding and careful, but this is not a two-way scenario.   But all in all, a special game that is not to be missed!!

★★★★★ - 'Do not miss this game'   PROS: - Vital decision making, the story is your own as the life of Fables often rests in your hands. - Excellent detective elements with little to influence your ideas. - A wonderful world with imaginative characters who are individual and interesting. - Fight scenes and interrogation are plentiful and a particular highlight. - The storyline is simply amazing right to the final moments as you fight to impress the town, controlling your own persona.  CONS: - A little buggy here and then when it comes to movement and lip syncing, very rare however. - I wish there was more, 5 episodes which took 8 hours to complete.  VERDICT?  The best tell tale game yet, I loved every minute.
Second season when?

This is the first Telltale game that I've completed, and it was worth every penny and minute.   The Wolf Among Us has a great story throughout which included very adult and real themes at time, its impossible to not end up feeling emotionally attached to some of the characters. You can either allow Bigby stay as the big bad wolf or try and turn a new leaf with the dialogue and action options, I personally tried to turn over a new leaf but sometimes someone just needed a little threatening.  On top of this the design of the game from menu screen, to each episode of the game, and the credits is lovely. My favourite character designs are Bigby Wolf - the subtley of his changes and his final form are great - and Bloody Mary -   her true form design is so good; the sounds accompanying her when walking, and how she shatters  . I'm just insanely impressed with how well this is put together.  Its fairly straight forward to complete the game with 100% achievements but there are a few things that you might miss depending on choices you make - some areas you need to pick to go to a certain destinaton first - but there are guides that'll help you figure out what you're missing and which chapters you might need to replay at the end.
Again, Telltale bring us an amazing adventure game where all your choices actually matters and keep you on your toes during 5 episodes !  Get it now and play as 'Bigby the Big Bad Wolf'.
Second season when?
Great characters, fun and intriguing story! This was my first TellTale game and I found myself enjoying it much more than I thought I would.

This is a great game with a beautiful and detailed story. I feel that it fits very well with the Fables comic universe! There were a few references to the comic as well which was really exciting to me.  The twists and turns that telltale is beginning to be known for were shocking yet did not feel out of place. Even after finishing the game multiple times I feel that there are more scenes to watch.  This game is definitely not for everyone though!  There is more story than gameplay and it often feels more like an interactive movie than a game. There are the occasional glitches (this choice is blank!) and inconsistencies, but overall it's a beautiful game.
This game is awesome. Highly recommended if you like a compelling story and amazing characters. 10/10

*Disclaimer* - Very personal review. This game is the most thoughtfully constructed, story driven, out of the box, work of art game that I've ever played. It's beaten the best action story driven games I've played for a couple of reasons. (ex. being Bioshock Infinite, Red Dead Redemption, Final Fantasy Games, ect.) And while I'm an avid multiplayer gamer this one dragged me in to finish my playthrough in just a couple of hours a night to make it like I was watching an addictive television series, and wanting the last episodes cliff hanger ending be redeemed by the next episode as it would do just the same. I was dragged into a world of adult content with twisted fairy tales as the characters from your favorite child hood books and movies were dragged out of their fantasy and into the real world with real world problems. The Story follows the Big Bad Wolf ( or Big-B as he's called in the suburb of exiled fairy tales), and his new role as the sheriff and soon to be detective as the crime stricken suburb is torn to pieces by murders and alliances that'll make you be asking yourself: 'Who did it?' after everysingle turn in the story driven episodic crime drama. A part from the action adventure games I've played significantly more in my time my time as a gamer, this one drags away to a gritty drama that's meant to be portrayed in a cartoon or even an irl drama, but is well executed with the master point and click decision making, left of right, top or bottom, plot this game has, which TellTall Games pulls of better than ever in this original classic. It's mean, raunchy, nefarious, and will have you on the edge of your seat uncovering the evils of your childhood fairy tales one by one. I give it a 9.5/10 to jump on the 'overwhelmingly positive[ness]' bandwagon this game is recieving but always falls short in it's replay value, but who knows? You're different from me. You could play this game seven times through and find every single time to be a new adventure with different answers to the story lines optional paths. Which is great because that's what these games excell at. So if you've watched every epsidoe of Law and Order SVU and have a knack for a fantasy story book story time, you definitely won't be leaving your seat from start to finish.

Noir with a fantasy twist and really great visuals.  The plot/characters are executed less smoothly than in The Walking Dead, but I still got played by them damsels and felt real wolf's hunger for vengeance in the final chapters.  If you've never played any TTG game - better start with The Walking Dead. If you like TTG stuff and noir - better check it out.
Brother's grimm fairy tales come to life in a detective noir story that will keep you guessing till the very end.  10/10

I've become a real fan of telltale games lately and this is another nice addition to their collection. Its an Interesting game and art style. Its collection of fable/grimm type characters and story took a little while to grow on me but once it did i really enjoyed it. Where the game really succeeds for me is the middle chapters and beginning to join the dots between the murders in town and making the tough decisions to protect those who are possibly escaping their stereotypes or the tough situations they have fallen into to get by in this new world.
Fantastic story, I had a great time and I cant wait till more chapters come out!!

I ♥♥♥♥ing love this game.  The style is alluring, the colors are vivid, the characters are entertaining, the setting is exceptional, the story is enthralling, the dames are damey, and the wolves go howlin' oh-so-good.  Great game, really.

A 'howling' good time, bad puns aside another great story from telltale games filled with quick-time events, various consequential choices and in-depth characters. The wolf among us Is full of humorous, sad and angry situations definitly recommend.

If you've played a Telltale game before you know what to expect here but within the context of these types of games I feel certain aspects in The Wolf Among Us are better polished than other offerings from the developer. Take for example the transitions from one scene to the next, and the facial animations; they're executed extremely well in comparison to many of Telltale's other games.   Besides that the world of fables within The Wolf Among Us is extremely intriguing and the game as a whole touches on many mature themes and problems with modern society while still being ultimately grounded in a fantasy world and allowing the player to step in the shoes of the big bad wolf.  From my perspective if you want a thrill ride like The Walking Dead you're looking at the wrong game, but if you want a better told more interesting story intended for a more mature individual you should buy The Wolf Among us. It doesn't hurt that the action sequences available within the game are ultimately better executed as well, you just have to be patient sometimes before you get to them.

With the Wolf Among Us Telltale have delivered another brilliant interactive story. This game plays similarly to the Walking Dead in that it's a point and click game where you have various dialogue choices as well as other choices to make that effect the story of the game. The Wolf Among Us is based on the Fable series of comics. It's set in a part of New York inhabited by the characters from the nursery rhymes and fairytales such as Snow White and Mr.Toad. All these mythical characters had to move to our world after there Homeland was destroyed.  It sounds like it might be a story for children but anything but with the characters inhabiting a gritty dark world where they have to deal with inequality and poverty and the politics that go with it. In the game you play Bigby (The Big Bad Wolf) who is the sheriff of Fabletown. He gets embroiled in a murder case and indoing so finds himself caught up in the politics of Fabletown itself as he tries to solve the crime.   As already said the gameplay is very similar to the Walking Dead as is the comic book style of animation which looks great. The games main strength is it's story which i found enthralling and it really hooked me in. The characters in this game are brilliant as well and you'll meet a lot of memorable characters from the fairytales you would have heard as a child. The great thing is the characters are all very realistic in that they have their own problems like being alcholics or struggling to pay rent and feel a lot more fleshed out than the more 2 dimensional characters they are in the old fairytales.  The Good: -Fantastic story with some really characters -Game looks nice with that comic book style of animation -All episodes are released now so no waiting a month or two for the next episode. -Game has decent replay value as it's worth playing again but making different choices to see how it changes the story.  The Bad: -Not a lot really. I suppose the only one i can think of is that the gameplay is identical to that off the Walking Dead. Wold have been nice to see some new ideas introduced in this area.  Overall I loved this game. More than i enjoyed the Walking Dead. I know this game will mostly appeal to WD fans but this is really great in it's own right and should be a must-buy for anyone looking for a game with a great story. Especially now all the episodes have been released. 10/10
Telltale is at it again, FANTASTIC episode #1!  Does the comic books justice and then some, definatly check it out!

This is my second time playing this & I felt like I missed so much from the first save. It was awesome seeing familar childhood Fables trying to live a normal life, but with a mysterious murderer lurking around. Bigby & Snow White are amazing lead characters. I hope to see more of them and the rest of the Fables introduced this season & cannot wait for season two!!!

This is my fourth Telltale game and I can tell you that it doesn't disappoint!  The Wolf Among Us brings you onto a mysterious murder case that you have to solve. It's like CSI but with old fairytale characters. The story kept me guessing throughout the entire playthrough. It really drew me in.  Although, compared with some of Telltale's other games, this one definitely has a darker backdrop to it. Of course, that's how it has created such a great atmosphere that really makes this mystery shine. You've got this dark, overshadowing vibe that follows you as you play through each scene.  This game is really fighting for the top spot of Telltale's games. If you like playing their games, this one is definitely one to play through. You won't regret it.  See you on the other side. Godspeed!

There is a lot to love about this game. The style, the story and the music are just fantastic. The only down side is the episodic nature of the game means you can be left for several months waiting to see what happens next.

This game is casual, yet addicting. It has great depth of story, character, and world, and awesome art. I really enjoyed playing it.  However, I wonder about how much impact your choices really have on the game. For the most part, you seem to be headed in the same direction no matter what. Also, without the ability to skip cut scenes, it is unrealistic to replay the game. I would love to replay the whole thing making all different choices just to see what happens. I know we should not have a skip option during the first playthrough, but maybe the developers could add that as an unlocked option once you finish all 5 episodes.  If the game looks interesting to you, it is well worth getting.

This game is so addicting I found myself thinking about it during the day. Bigsby is a GREAT character to control, there is nothing worse than a main character who doesn't speak or react. Bigsby is raw, he acts on impulse and he has a history, a pretty gory one.  I don't read comics so I cannot comment on what was better storywise but playing this game made me want to read the comics. Playing threw the various fables in a corrupt, dirty fable town was more fun than I care to admit. Yes, this game is very wordy and I worried about that, I am known to skup cutscenes with to much text, but I really enjoyed reacting to the situation. A lot of the choices led to the same outcome but I still enjoyed getting there.  At the end you see the percentage of Steam players who chose a specific option/path. I was glad to read that over 80% didn't choose to send Colin to the farm. I was heartbroken for him. I want to replay it but I wish there was a way to skip the text that I have already played threw.

Chapter One made for a fun couple of hours. The atmosphere was great and the art style of Fables really works well with Telltale's Art Direction. Of course the 'adventure' parts could be a bit more invoved than just 'click everything clckable then talk to people'. The choices all work with Bigby's established character and for readers of the comic books the dynamics between characters should be an extra treat. Where the game is let down are of course the QTEs that also plagued the Walking Dead game, though the action sequences work better in this game, once you remember to always have a hand resting over Q+WASD and another on the mouse. People who do not read the comic may be at an advantage when it comes to enjoying the mystery, not knowing how various characters' futures will work out. A nice extra is the Book of Fables, a collection of Lore unlocks giving background on characters and the world.

As of this review, I had just finished Episode 2 of 5. Those of you familiar with The Walking Dead game made by Telltale Games will definitely enjoy this game. The game plays very similarly in many aspects such as quick time events and the same style of conversation choices. This game takes a fun twist on the Fables you grew up hearing about and takes it to a very dark place. The twists and turns of the story will keep you on edge and keep you playing. Each episode has lasted roughly 1 & 1/2 to 2 hours so far so in the long run i'm assuming it'll be 8-10 hours of gameplay total for an entire playthrough. Telltale Games continues to deliver with another unique story and entertaining game with The Wolf Among Us. I picked it up on a Steam sale for $8 and it was well worth it.

First off this is more of an interactive storybook than a real game. That said, the story is extremely compelling, the art style beautiful, and the characters complex and believable. The gameplay itself goes by really quickly so make good use of that pause button or you'll feel rushed and make mistakes. Most of the game is looking for and putting clues together, and most games either make the clues so easy to work with that you feel like a coddled child, or so difficult to work with that you get frustrated and give up and look everything up on a wiki. This game though does the clues PERFECTLY, and you will really feel a sense of accomplishment when you put things together. You will also feel very in control of the story, even when you're not. The choices you get to make as Bigby Wolf really let you define his character. Are you a good man with a terrible past, trying to redeem yourself? Are you simply a law-enforcer, tired of fighting? Or are you still just 'The Big Bad Wolf'?

The Wolf Among Us (Episode 1) is the latest game from Telltale Games and the first of a new series. Based on DC Vertigo's 'Fables' comic series, you play the role of Bigby Wolf (formerly the Big Bad Wolf of Little Red Riding Hood fame) and now the sheriff of Fabletown - a hidden world of fable characters in New York City. The last Telltale series I played was 'Sam & Max', so I wasn't expecting the more 'graphic novel' approach to the game. There are sections of the game which play more like traditional point-n-click adventures, but with all the potential hotspots in the area highlighted for you, it's less about hunting for things on screen and more about clicking on everything to unlock more of the story. The story is an extremely violent affair dealing with a murder in Fabletown. This is not a game for kids. The language is bad, lots of cursing, and the violence is pretty violent.   The characters, voice acting and art are all absolutely first rate. The game itself is fun, but pretty easy. Even the action sequences, which involve hitting keys quickly in order to cause actions or avoid harm, are pleasantly forgiving. The game is more about choices than action, however. The game tells you when you've made a choice which will have lasting impact on the game. One downside is that the episode is on the short side. I played it from start to finish, including the tutorial, in under 2 hours. The ending came abruptly and left me sitting at the keyboard wondering what to do next. The game provides some feedback at the end of the episode about how your choices compare to other players of the game (38% of players make the same choice you did, for example). It's an interesting statistic, and from a psychology standpoint, it would be really cool to see more stats and more detail, but I suppose there's a limit to what they can show you without making it boring or spoiling future episodes.   It's a great story so far. I found myself lost in it for the 2 hours it took to complete. If you can pick it up on sale, I recommend that - it makes the shortness more palletable. I know there will be more episodes, but if they are all roughly the same length, we're only talking about 10 hours or so gameplay for the season. That seems low for the full price cost of the game - no matter how good the production values are. I highly recommend The Wolf Among Us, at any price, but with the holiday sale going on, there's no reason not to get it if you can score the discount.

I feel I've played enough to properly review this game now :)  I've been holding off on getting any of TellTale's games before, simply because I'm not a fan of episodic gameplay. When this went on sale though I said to myself 'Well, I've heard good things about this game, can't hurt to give it a try.'  I start the game up with moderate expectations. I'm usually skeptic about games even when they are praised by others.  The first thing I'm greeted with is the, to me really nice Main Menu music, it gives a sense of mystery and makes me wanna get into the game. I fiddle with the settings, for some reason it put my resolution at the lowest setting so I had to change that, then I start a new game.  It doesn't take long for me to get connected with the main character, I really like the idea of a villain trying to turn over a new leaf in this new world. After some QTE sequences I get to the end of the prologue for the chapter and the intro starts to play, again I'm amazed by the music.  Based solely on that first little part of the game I knew I was hooked. The story telling is great, the characters are great and the music is amazing.  Now I haven't caught up to the current chapter yet, but I've played the first two so far and to me this game is an easy 10/10.  Scores for those that are into them:  Graphics: 8/10 It's an interesting style but it can look a bit smudgey at times. Music: 10/10 Simply amazing. Voice acting: 10/10 Really good job on this, which is always nice in a game that relies heavily on talking. Story: 10/10 Sooooo captivating and exciting, once I start a chapter it's really hard to stop before the end of it. Gameplay: 9/10 Only thing I ever have issues with is reading all the conversational options in the time I have to choose.  Overall: 10/10! Get this game! (If you don't mind a completely storydriven game with quite a few QTEs)
If you liked The Walking Dead, you will surely like this. The story is excellent and leaves you begging for more!   10/10

I enjoyed the game, but mostly from having read the comics. I enjoyed seeing some of the characters I know and love make appearances and getting to know new ones. I loved exploring Fabletown with Bigby and and trying my best to help out the other fables. However... This game is guilty of not really leaving much of an impact once you're done with it. In the end it feels like everything you've done was for nothing and that the developers were very limited to what kind of fable characters they could use in their story and how they could portray them.  ^Saying that based on their villain, which frankly I found very weak and sadly bland. They build him up so much and in the end he's no more interesting than a wet potato.  There was another Villain I liked though, henchman-type, not gonna spoil who it is that you have to battle near the end of the game that quickly became one of my favourite characters in the entire game... She's not the main villain though, it's not a good sign when the main villain's henchmen are more interesting than him/herself.  There's much more to be said about this game, sadly negative, it mostly has to do with the ending. They had such a vast universe to work with great characters, but in the end they just didn't know how to put the pieces together very well and you end up with kind of a mess.  I'm worried about spoiling too much and being too specific, but the ending was the weakest part of the game.  There are a lot of small details in the game I enjoyed and found clever, which was a saving grace for me, but big picture wise this wasn't a very strong Telltale g. game.  Overall I'll say that this game needs a lot of polish and fine adjustments and probably some rewriting at parts, particularily the end.   I will recommend it regardless, I see a lot of potential and mostly enjoyable characters and an exciting world. There's a gem here, but it's not easy to tell from the ending of it. I hope there will be a season two and I hope the writers will have learned from their mistakes by then.

If you're a fan of the Fables comic series, play this right now. If you haven't read the comics...you should probably see to that; you're missing out.  Shameless fanboying aside, The Wolf Among Us is fantastic. I love the graphics; all rich colors and deep shadows, beautiful and stylized (and they look just like Buckingham's work on the comic). The audio is quite good as well; the voice acting is top-notch (the antagonist introduced at the end of Episode 3 is particularly well-done) and the music is nicely atmospheric. As far as gameplay, it's less like playing a game and more like watching a miniseries where you have some degree of control over the action on screen. Really, though, it's the storyline that does it, mixing noir and detective conventions with fairy tales and magic, full of interesting characters and just enough unanswered questions to make me desperately want a sequel.  Play this. You won't regret it.

Honestly, I have never been a fan of adventure games, neither old-school classics nor modern 'TellTale'-style games. But I finally forced myself to play this and I'll have to say: This was some of the most fun I had with a game in a long time!  The story is dark, but not all-out torture porn. The characters are memorable, relatable, hateable or anything in between. The graphics and design are gorgeous.  I have only played through this game once, so I can't really say anything about replayability or the consequences of your choices. But while playing, you definitely FEEL like your actions affect the story dramatically.  There are QTEs in this game, but they do not really bother me all that much. They are fairly easy and ♥♥♥♥-ups do not lead to instant failure and restart.  I'd highly recommend this game to anyone, even people like me who do not really like other adventure games

[SPOILERS MAYBE. I dunno but read at your own risk I have no idea what qualifies as one anymore]   With the release of each episode since the first, I was racing to my computer in anticipation to see what would happen to Bigby and the residents of Fabletown! The Wolf Among us is an excellent introduction to new people who have yet to read the comic book series, and I'm glad to have followed this season through till the end.   With the 2-4 choices that are given to you, TWAU gives you room to play it multiple times with different styles (There will only be one true way to how Bigby acts, however); do you play as the strong and silent type, or just be a complete jerk? How about a do-gooder who tries to act for the best of Fabletown? How about something in between, or do you want to play by your own rules? It's really up to you.   The characters have their own dynamic personality, something that I find to be a really hard thing to do in games. Players play to win the game, to further progress so we can see the end; what happens after that. It's up to the developers to make sure we can bond with the characters involved and not just sit there blankfaced to what consequences fall upon the people around the player. Beauty and Beast try to look out for one another, although they don't know that they've sunken themselves in to the point of danger. Snow is bossy and doesn't see her own mistakes until she realizes this due to the people around her. Toad is (rightfully) angry at the system as a whole, and is in an unwinnable situation; a testament that not everything can be won in this game. Even the minor characters like Flycatcher and Hans were impressionable characters. Bloody Mary is a huge dongle though and I really hate her guts holy jesus and joseph and mary (SEE WHAT I DID THERE).   ....This game is great. That's really all I can say about it, really. Telltale has hooked me, they really have. I don't try to find flaws about games unless they're SUPER apparent. It has some, no doubt; no game is perfect. But because of TWAU, I will be scouring to find the comic books and read them.   People should buy this if they like interactive storytelling games like this; you most likely won't be disappointed.

If not for the Walking Dead, then surely this game made me a fan of Telltale's 'story-telling' games. Though I'm still not a fan of the 'episodic release' model, it's not that much of a bother because people like me will just hold off on playing it until everything is finished. It's nothing different than how I treat other series like TV Shows and Anime; a sentiment that is spawned out of fear for cliffhangers and wanting to see/experience the story to a satisfying end.. in one big sitting.  If you played the Walking Dead or seen how it's played, this game is pretty similar except that it's more cinematic with a bit less adventure elements. That's not to say that it's inferior because if anything, it allows for you to focus and enjoy more of the story instead of breaking it up and have you puzzle around to progress further. Action scenes are composed mostly of Quick Time Events which I'm sure some people frown upon but to be fair, Walking Dead's button prompts and '360 Quickscoping' doesn't really qualify for a better combat/action mechanic. It's the same in the end, because the game(s) follow along a 'hardscripted' line with a bit of room for personal choices which may affect how the story unfolds but doesn't really alter it's course.  So it pretty much comes down to whether you like the story/setting of the game. Wolf Among Us is a mature twist on the fairy tale / fable universe whereas Walking Dead is.. well.. the Walking Dead. Both stories/games are really great but as for personal preference; I like the Wolf Among Us' premise and storyline much more. These games now really have me hyped up for Telltale's upcoming series.. Borderlands and Game of Thrones. If you plan on playing them on day 1 of release / per episode, the price may seem a bit steep initially.. but in their entirety, I'd say they're probably worth it. In any case, WD and Wolf Among Us surely are.

*NO SPOILERS* I just finished this game, took be almost a year to get around to playing it but now that i have i don't regret it. I loved the story and was engaged to it from the very beginning and really wanted to find the out what happened, who did what. I also really felt like i was the big bad wolf and i wanted to make the right decisions for the benefit of fabletown. My point is i cared about what happened in this game and it takes a very good game to do that and Telltale seem to find a way to do this in all of their games. This game also has plot twists so just when you think you have it all figured out you find you are wrong because not everything is as it appears.  Make sure you check this game out and if you enjoy it you will enjoy telltales other games such as The Walking Dead.  9/10

Is it worth it?   Definitely, a unique experience that you should give a try.   Amazing game from start to end   - filled with complicated twists and [i/] very subtle [/i]hints.  The gameplay : What you would expect from a game made by TellTale  The story : An engaging mystery-based plot - all filled with complex twists. The ending will just leave you thinking for a while, trust me, it will.  The visuals : Nice cell-shaded art like every TellTale game.  The music : Quite satisfying retro-sounding score.  Overall : An amazing experience from start to end with a very strong story; keeping you engaged throughout your playthrough - however you may encounter some rather odd bugs.

So far the best adventure detective game I have ever played in my life. Guys from Telltale Games really know how to do a perfect game with perfect story and perfect voice-acting. It's true that the animations aren't the best, but with such a good story, it doesn't matter at all. I wasn't sure about the Fables setting when I went into this game, but I'm glad I played it.   Another one of Telltale's delightful graphic novels. I say that because they aren't adventure games anymore. Since the last two episodes of the Walking Dead Season 2, there have been no puzzles in the the Telltale Games. You might move around for a while, but overwhelmingly, the Wolf Among Us takes place in dialouge and quick time events. Even in the first 20 minutes of the first episode, you only get control of your character's movement twice and even then only for a few seconds. The characters are locked onto very stiff rails and although there's a lot of pointing and clicking on various options. Even in the very few investigations, the game solves the problems for you. It would be like in LA Noire if you picked up a piece of evidence and immediatley knew how and why it was connected to the case.   Like the Walking Dead Series, no choice you make really matters for more than a few seconds, but the story stands tall and strong on its own, which makes this game well worth playing. The great thing about storys in a fantasy setting is that plotholes are usually patched up by magic and Wolf Among Us makes very good use of its magic, leaving only a few massive potholes right at the finale, which is honestly disappointing.   I also want to say that it sounds like Telltale really wanted John DiMaggio to play Bigby Wolf, as you can sometimes hear the character drop into a Marcus Fenix/Bulletstorm Grayson Hunt type voice. It's actually kind of distracting.   Regardless, the Wolf Among Us is great fun to watch and to play. Its story kept me emotionally invested and its characters kept me interested in every moment inbetween.

The characters are firmly established early on- I'd seen the comic in forbidden before but never really knew what it was about- and it was really cool to see if I could recognise characters. As far as the actual gameplay goes, I wasn't sure what to expect with this one. Its largely character driven cutscenes and player choice. Infact player choice is a huge part of this game! Combat is fast clicking and quicktime events, between cutscene and combat is almost point and click adventure as you look for clues in your investigation. I was impressed with flat out how much the player's choices could change things each time through! If you enjoy character driven plots, dark reiterations on fairy tale characters and immersive gameplay, you chould check out this first episode!
First two episodes, break a shotglass in a man's face, burn his hand with a cigarette. Fourth episode we're best buds.  [Glass him]/10

I just bought this game yesterday and I've been so enthralled with it that I've already finished the first two chapters. The story is written extremely well, with choices that are hard to make. This is not a game where you will be afforded the chance to study up before you make a choice (like Fallout or Deus Ex). You need to be quick, decisive and ready for the consequences. This game will definitely warrent several playthroughs.   Other than the excellent story, the game is beautiful. The neon colors and cell shading give the definite impression of a comic book. Sometimes my eyes glaze over while playing, just because of how gorgeous the game is.  If there was any doubt in your mind, I recommend a definite buy. I got my copy at a reduced price, so if 25 dollars is a bit steep for you, I would recommend grabbing it now (while it's at 15 for midweek madness), or when a sale comes around. No matter what price you purchase this at, though, you will not regret it.

Who's afraid of the Big Bad Wolf? Based on the Fables graphic novels, The Wolf Among Us is a fantastic game. Fairytale figures - known as Fables - have left The Homeland to find a new existence on Earth, most of them deciding to settle in New York. You play as Bigby Wolf, a detective who is employed by 'Fabletown's' council. When a Fable ends up being murdered in mysterious circumstances, Sheriff Bigby sets out to investigate the case.  It is a great story, with lots of little twists and some pretty tough choices. If my summary of the story seemed a bit too brief, well, that's intentional, because there is literally no reason to play this game for anything but its story. This is a 'Telltale narrative game' that plays exactly like Telltale's The Walking Dead. The game consists of light exploration, lots of conversations with timed dialogue choices and QTE combat scenes. Personally, I found the combat in this game much more enjoyable than in The Walking Dead because you are playing as a really powerful character who can cause some serious damage. As things get more heated, Bigby becomes more and more wolf-like... and it's great.  The graphics of this game are also phenomenal. The colours are very vibrant and the general aesthetic is just lovely. It is an excellent example of how style alone can make a game visually gorgeous. The atmosphere is pretty much flawless, with a solid synth soundtrack that is never quite in-your-face. I appreciate how subtle the music often is, personally.  There are only two downsides to this game. The first one is... It's a Telltale Tool game. Everything looks great, for certain, but the animations are rather janky. It is not overly jarring, but... You can clearly tell that they are using outdated animation models.   The second downside is not really a downside, but it is certainly something that requires some getting-used to. Bigby is not exactly a nice man-wolf-thing. A seemingly innocuous dialogue choice like 'I'm hunky-dory' will make him aggressively blurt out 'I'm just HUNKY-DORY, THANK you for ASKING!!!'. Now, I am not sure if I am giving Telltale too much credit here, but it seems to me that they have intentionally done this to illustrate how difficult it is for Bigby to keep his bestial nature in check. If my theory is correct, I'll give them loads of credit for that. If it is not, well... Then the dialogue options should have been clearer, if you ask me.  All in all, if you want a great story with a compelling premise and you do not mind a limited amount of actual gameplay, this is definitely the game for you.

The Wolf Among Us is a well crafted story wrapped in mystery, presented in Telltale's graphic style of cell-shading and point-and-click mechanic system. Through dialogue, scene investigation, and the occasional fight scene, I experienced a world that is well thought out (thanks to its source material), endlessly intriguing, and just plain gorgeous. The use of fairy tale characters and myths sets the stage for light familiarity with all of the characters, but turns your expectations for nearly every character on its head. The characters feel less like beasts and princesses and more like people who live in the real-world that is sprikled with principles of a fantasy story, which makes for an incredibly realistic experience of characterization and conversations between characters in an otherwise impossible setting.  This game may certainly not be for everyone, but I would most definitely recommend it to any individual looking for an alternative experience in gaming that is combined with the quality of a cable television series. I'm excited to play through the game a second time to discover what will occur differently upon making different decisions. I can only hope that a second season will be released sooner rather than later so I may lose myself once again in Fabletown to unravel more enigmas and to learn what it means to be human from the wolf among us.

I wasn't sure about the Fables setting when I went into this game, but I'm glad I played it.   Another one of Telltale's delightful graphic novels. I say that because they aren't adventure games anymore. Since the last two episodes of the Walking Dead Season 2, there have been no puzzles in the the Telltale Games. You might move around for a while, but overwhelmingly, the Wolf Among Us takes place in dialouge and quick time events. Even in the first 20 minutes of the first episode, you only get control of your character's movement twice and even then only for a few seconds. The characters are locked onto very stiff rails and although there's a lot of pointing and clicking on various options. Even in the very few investigations, the game solves the problems for you. It would be like in LA Noire if you picked up a piece of evidence and immediatley knew how and why it was connected to the case.   Like the Walking Dead Series, no choice you make really matters for more than a few seconds, but the story stands tall and strong on its own, which makes this game well worth playing. The great thing about storys in a fantasy setting is that plotholes are usually patched up by magic and Wolf Among Us makes very good use of its magic, leaving only a few massive potholes right at the finale, which is honestly disappointing.   I also want to say that it sounds like Telltale really wanted John DiMaggio to play Bigby Wolf, as you can sometimes hear the character drop into a Marcus Fenix/Bulletstorm Grayson Hunt type voice. It's actually kind of distracting.   Regardless, the Wolf Among Us is great fun to watch and to play. Its story kept me emotionally invested and its characters kept me interested in every moment inbetween.

The Wolf Among Us Season 1 - Sheriff Jackass (spoiler free)  Despite having played The Walking Dead Season 1, I was apprehensive about purchasing The Wolf Among Us. However, such notions proved unfounded shortly into the first episode. The Wolf Among Us is a prequel to the Fables comic book series which I've never read; you truly don't need to in order to enjoy this game. The Wolf Among us portrays various fairy tale characters tied together such as The Big Bad 'Bigby' Wolf, Snow White, Beauty and the Beast, and one of the Three Little Pigs in 'our' world; in a noir-esque downtrodden section of the Bronx. This game may ruin your childhood; in the world of Fables, ever present is prostitution, murder, and drugs amongst other crimes.  (If you've ever wanted to see the Little Mermaid pole dance topless, then this may be the game for you, you degenerate perv.)  You play as Bigby, the sheriff of Fabletown who must solve a string of murders which is something of a very rare occurrence. As to not give anything away, I will not say anymore. The only downside that I can possibly think of, albeit small, is the somewhat abrupt cliffhanger of an ending which there are various theories floating around as to what it could mean. However, there is supposed to be a season 2 to The Wolf Among us. Regardless, if you liked The Walking Dead game(s), what Nolan did for Batman in terms of realism, and/or you’re simply a kinky ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ who wants to see fairy tale characters degrade themselves, buy this game.

It's a Telltale game. Need I say more? Well, I think yes.  I too am one who now avoids these games because of their apparnt stagnant and stale nature, with old engines in use, dodgy animation and similar 'comic-book' art-style throughout all their games. Fortunately this copy was a gift to me. Having played the Walking Dead Series 1 and 2, I've grown tired of the formula as have many others. The occasional walking and interacting with obvious things, little in the way of creativity and/or puzzle solving, and certainly no choices that 'actually' mean anything. But, while Walking Dead has follow up series to think about, and so has to limit branches, Wolf Among Us does not and I feel this is much to the game's advantage for it feels like your choices actually do impact the 'overall picture' at the end of the game. By that I mean which characters are still around, and what they think of you. Obviously the story will play out the same regardless, it just may be with different friends or companions. But there is replay value there at least.  So, for those unfamiliar with the formula - it's an episodic series where you play as the Wolf in a community of Fables (characters from Fable tales put into human disguises in order to mingle with society. But something goes wrong in this fragile community, and being the 'Sheriff' it's up to you to investigate what is going on. There are a few twists and turns which are exiciting along the way.  Most of the game will involve one of the following: 1) Quick Time Events 2) Talking to people to trigger the next thing 3) Examining things to trigger people to talk to and/or the next thing. The controls are ok, character movment feels as sluggish as in the other games, but at least environments are not too big so exploring doesn't take an unecesary amount of time. So through the game you will be doing one of the above with a fair bit of moving from one person or obviously interactible object to another, and that's ok, a bit dull, but ok. Becuase in my opinon the story and atmosphere makes up for it - the voice acting really shines there too (though facial animation can be a bit trippy to me).  As with a lot of 'Who-Dunnits', and as already mentioned, there are a good number of twists and turns in this game, friendships are doubted, corruptions revealed, vigilantes unmasked and more, all along the way, because you are sherrif you effective choose how you want to run the community. Do you play Good-Cop and everyone is happy with you, but may continue to hide things, or do you play Bad Cop, knocking the truth out of people and making them resent you? There is a very strong theme of Justice throughout the series and it works pretty well, motivating many player actions and plot points which do not seem forced, but make sense.  I did encounter a few bugs here and there, nothing particularly bad, only requiring a couple of restarts on one occasion.  As a standalone series I do recommend it, especially if you enjoy crime shows on TV as it plays out very much like one of those, except you build your character as you go, rather than watching pre-established characters and relationships play out. Just be aware that at least half of the gameplay is a bit dull, uninspired and repetitive and will sometimes find yourself just wanting to get to the next bit of the story.

Probably the best story plot ever or at the very least has one of the best character that has ever been made in video games. Bigby the main character is the Sheriff and the Big Bad Wolf.
