The game “The wolf Among Us” is another master piece done by telltale games. I have played some games by them in the past such as “Sam and Max” series and the “The walking dead”. As always this company has created a master piece. The game has high replay value because depending on your moral choices the tale weaves into different outcomes. The story telling is actually great; I played the game in one day. I was so entailed with its plot that I needed to know what will happen by the end of the game, so I kept playing and playing until I beat it. The characters are likeable and the plot is easy to understand for those who have never read the comic “Fables”. After finishing the game, it made want to read the comic to know what happens next with Mr. Bigby Wolf and Snow white. I give it a 11/10.

SPOILER FREE  PRO   Probably the best voice acting I have heard in a game, all around, not sure who the VAs were but they felt proffesional, Bigby sounded like David Hayter(Solid Snake), but performed to a higher level in my opinion. Even the worst actors were better than the best actors I have heard in some big budget games. More of a statement about the quality of VAs in games I suppose, but these VAs definitely have chops. even the kid is really good.   A well-constructed narrative, particularly for this type of 'moral choice' game. Generally you get the obvious good and bad options, but this game has a bit more variance thnaks to the characters, and the option to remain silent. You will definitely be going to and from who you think is responsible for what happens. Seems short because it is only 5 episodes but each episode is a few hours. Though if you go into it with a poopsock mindset you are wasting your time and the games time, immerse yourself in it.   If you can't help but just rush through it catatonically, it's your own loss, but it is an easy game for achievements, as they unlock as you play through the story. I do seem to have missed one or two, probably based on choices I have made, but really easy to fix if I have the time. If all you care about is your steam score, whatever it's called, this is a good game for you.   Good mix of humor and grit, the tone seems kind of light to being with, but the more you play the more twisted it gets, and the more you question your morality, and past decisions. Liberal use of language helps to make the tone feel more adult, and the characters more real. The darkness isn't over the top and try hard, just kind of sprinkled around, for instance if you look carefully in the background of the office there appears to be a man hanging. Also if you are mean to the toad kid you have issues.  CON   The cell-shaded graphics weren't breathtaking, but still a bit refreshing. For how recent the game was I was a bit surprised by the quality, compared to some other recent cell-shaded games, but I suppose it is a compromise for all of the other effort that has gone into it.   A few glitches. Some of them could have potentially made a mess like conversation options saying 'this option is blank' but elliciting responses. I thought it was some kind of trippy dream sequence but glad I reloaded the game just in case. Also got one time when I walked into a corner and then couldn't escape it not matter what I tried. Nothing loading from the last checkpoint can't fix in my experience.  Combat is QTE-based, so don't expect a challenge, but how you fight makes a difference, I will leave it at that.   The preview at the end of each episode could probably be done without, surprises are a strength in the game so taking that away isn't ideal, though understandable with the episode release format, you want to give customers a hook. The 'previously on' would be nice to be able to skip too.   FINAL WORD   Initially I really didn't want to play this game at all, it just seemed linear, short, and childish by how I had seen it advertised. It was only thanks to seeing a friend play it that it caught my interest, with a toad telling you to '♥♥♥♥ off'. I got it on sale warily, but now I have experienced it I would say it was probably worth the price. Defintely going to check out other Telltale games, now that my prejudice has been dispelled.

Telltale has really cut corners here. Subsequent episodes of this episodic series were released on sheldue and that probably had an impact on quality. Almost all chapters after first one had overall much less player exploaration and were much shorter, barely lasting more than an hour. Let's not forget that Telltale is still a small studio, and perhaps tackling four projects at a time is too much for them. On a positive note TWAU is a very competent adaptation of original comics. I especially liked gritty, 80s-feel noir story, filled with memorable characters, each with distinct motivations. Voice acting is of course top-notch as ever and it is nice to see some vibrant colours after The Walking Dead. Good game, too bad it was rushed.

This is a great RPG game that really requires you letting it pull you in to the story to get the most out of it. You can play it and not get immersed but you will not enjoy it as much. My 6 year old played with me and absolutely loves it. The musical score is great and story too.

I would recommend picking up The Wolf Among Us on sale, because I completed the entire game in about 5 1/2 hours. If you're an RPG fan, or have any remote interest in RPGs, don't miss TWAU. It's a fantastic game, and one of the few where I felt that my choices did have some impact on the plot. The characters are interesting and the plot is well written and paced nicely. Personally, I don't feel like Telltale needs to make a second season. The ending is a bit of a cliff hanger, but is satisfying and leaves a bit of mystery once the game wraps up. It's a great game that I would highly recommend picking up during an upcoming sale.

Ok, this game got me to start reading the FABLES series comics. I like the idea of Fables living in modern day New York City hiding from a so called adversary that drove them out of their homelands.   What is a Fable? Remember those stories by the Brothers Grimm? Well they made a game based on the comics they created with a unique storyline.   The game centers around Bigby Wolf (aka The Big Bad Wolf) who has become the Sheriff of Fabletown. Each character that gets introduced has already lived their fairytale life and is living in the modern day city. The characters that are in the game really do give this story a backbone. As with most Tell Tale games, I do enjoy the choices you are given that affect your ending of the game. It almost reminds me of that book series 'Choose Your Own Adventure' by Edward Packard.  Back to the game, the story gets deep and is almost like a murder mystery you have to solve. For those of you who haven't played a Tell Tale Series game, It's like watching a movie with you making the decisions as to what your character does next. I'd highly recommend playing this game and try to get different outcomes.

SPOILER FREE: Possibly my favorite game of all time. Up there with the likes of Fallout, Majora's Mask and Grand Theft Auto, this game is a must play. This game follows Bigby Wolf, a Sherrif in Fabletown. Since this is an episodic adventure, I must state how the episodes are split at key points and cliffhangers. Here are Pros and Cons for each episode.  Episode 1: 10/10 Pros One of the best ways to start off a game ever. Difficult choices effecting the whole game within the first hour. Character devolpment is paced finely. Major plot decission around the end Cons Investigation is the only investigation in the game. Terrible glitch that occurs frequently to hinder immersion, a glitch removing the first cutscene and adding blank choices.  Episode 2: 7/10 Pros Interigation has Good cop Bad cop route, suited for your choice. Continuation of the story speeds up in this part, as opposed from the slow pacing of last part. Shocking revelation at the end is the only major plot point Cons Continuaty from the 'Next Episode' clips is incorrect. Anti-climactic story arc contiuation from the last episode. -1. Terrible glitch that occurs frequently to hinder immersion, a glitch removing the first cutscene and adding blank choices.   Episode 3: 9/10 Pick from 3 Places to visit in order to find the 'Killer'. Plot point that will have effect on. Werewolf Bigby. Introduction of my favorite villian of all time. Choice between Sparing a life and ending a life. Cons: Terrible glitch that occurs frequently to hinder immersion, a glitch removing the first cutscene and adding blank choices. Hillarious glitch that makes Bigby Pole dance. Top lel. None other to think about.  Episode 4: 8/10 Pros Spend the entire episode on hunt for a certain shard of a certain object. Trying to track down the killer. Nice story Cons Terrible glitch that occurs frequently to hinder immersion, a glitch removing the first cutscene and adding blank choices. Although nice story, Straight forward and Bland. Still manages to screw up continuity. -1.  Episode 5: 9.5/10 Pros  Best gameplay from this series. Tear Jerking Ending. Major ending revalation. The choice is yours to kill the killer, or not, at any given point. Best supporting character ever has huge plot twist. Can't wait for season 2. Cons No matter what choice you make, the Citizens of Fabletown are upset. (Blank Box bug fixed)  OVERALL: 95/100 Great Game. Gripping. Tear Jerking. ACTUALLY GOOD Quick Time Events. Branching Dialouge surpassing The Walking Dead series. Most Bugs worked out.

The Wolf Among Us is a tightly paced Noir Thriller by the storytelling masters Telltale studios. Those looking for a change of setting from the fantastic The Walking Dead series would do well to check this out.  Be warned though, TWAU is alot darker in tone and does not have a child protaganist to offer the occasional lighthearted moments. This is a story almost nihilistic in nature where violence is often the only way to solve problems.  Still, there is a certain morbid fascination in taking a journey with these deeply flawed and damaged characters. Dark it may be, but dull it is not (imo).

Rating:  ★★★★☆   Who Should Buy this Game? : Wolf Among Us is a very unique game; it gory, dark and contains nudity - so it may not a game for all audiences. It is also not your typical point and click adventure that many people may associate to such style games. Wolf Among Us should be taken to heart as an interactive story with forgiving quick time events. So if you are expecting the depth of something like,  The Secret of Monkey Island, Blade Runner, Myst etc.  you may be in for a let down. Or if you are some one looking for a puzzle adventure style game similar to Sam and Max or Myst - this game is not for you. But if you just want a great story to just sit down, watch and be a part of you are in for one heck of a ride.   Synopsis:  Wolf Among Us is based on the comic book series Fables written by Bill Willingham. Without having to ruin the story - which is covered beautifully throughout the game and through the extra 'Fable Book Content'accessed through the main menu - it is essentially a murder mystery. Something foul is happening in Fable town and you as the town sherrif has to find out who really is behind the killings and decide how you want to dispense justice. Will you kill anyone who gets in your way? Or try to break the sterotype of being the Big Bad Wolf? The choices you make will shape the communities opinion toward you.    Game play wise  - the game in heart is an interactive story, with very forgiving quick time events. Infact there was a point in time where almost the entire combat I didn't press a single key just to see what happens. With the exception of the last obivious fatality which would have happened if I didn't react - it had no lasting impression on the game by missing a few quick time events. In other words it is very forgiving if you make a few mistakes along the way. This game shouldn't be played thinking there is only 1 right answer. Every answer is the right answer, as you are the one who shapes the story to decide the ultimate outcome and the fate of Fable. If you keep 'replaying' elements - you will probably ruin the experience. Choose what you believe is the best option and force your self to stick with it, to see how your choices finally sets the end tone of the game. Then replay the game with different choices, and see how things turn out. The entire game will last about 4 - 5 hours for a single play through, with each episode lasting for around 45 minutes. If you know what to expect, you will deffinetly enjoy the story and writing which is superb.   Cons:   I did experience maybe 2 crashes throughout the entire game, which resulted in me having to restart 1 chapter. Also in one of the episodes the animation and voice acting is a bit wonky as either one of the voice actors changed inbetween - or her lines were cut up so she sounds if her voice was done by a translation synthesizer. Though she is only a side character who only has about 5 minutes of screen time through the entire game at most, so it isn't a major issue - just annoying. There are also a lot of loose ends by the end of the game, but as I understand it - a season 2 should be coming out. Even then the major arc does get answered, but all your decisions will not have an impact in this season as some will be carried on to season 2.     Summary:  If you want a great story and looking for a casual cheap game, this game is worth every penny even at full price. It has great replability. solid story and a unique art style. But if you are some one who is more interested in puzzles and more elements of an interactive nature, this game may not be a good option for you. Either way if your on the fence, you should deffinetly give it a shot.  See yall around. -Swat

My Impression:  Telltale did really well with this game. Story was amazing and always kept you engaged. There's more storyline choices than fight scenes. I enjoyed that, some people might not. Amazing game in a rising genre.    Positive:  + Great story + Great characters + Good replayability with how the chapter format is set up. I am the type of person who can't watch a movie twice, but I can see myself playing this game again. + I loved the style of graphics, it may turn people off though. + Only like one or two instances where I didn't feel like the choices were something I would say. They all have varied choices. + The stats at the end of each chapter with the % of people that took that choice was neat. + Nudity, it may turn people off on the game, but it was story based.   Cons:  - Short, beat the game in 10 hours (wish it was longer, but not really a con) - Bug in Chapter 5 that scared me that I might have to restart the chapter, had to close game and re open and start from checkpoint. - Not a con for me, but theres more dialog choices than action scenes with button combinations.  Overall fun game, and worth the play. I would recommend this to anyone who asked me if the game was worth buying. Probably the best game in the genre.  10/10  I wish I could erase my memories and play this masterpiece over and over.

I recommend this game, but it is disappointing.  It is a visual novel (not a point-and-click adventure), made with top-notch production values. Graphics, scene direction, voice acting, choreography, are all as good as you would find in an excellent movie or graphic novel. It's a treat. It's why I'm giving this a game a thumbs up. Hell, the perfect portrayal of Colin the pig is reason enough to play this game!  The game world is interesting and creative, but the concept is unbelievable and quite silly, and the awe wears off pretty fast. Note that it is quite dark, with graphic depictions of violence and death, and even features gratuitous sex, because I guess that's what's needed to make something 'gritty' and 'adult-themed.'  Unfortunately, the story, modeled as a detective story, is poorly crafted. You do not feel anything like a detective: gameplay is more about 'press any key to continue' to the next clue than involving much thought on your part: your choice is often about where to go first, but you're going to get to the same place eventually, so who cares? There are areas to explore ... but they just have one exit and no items to click on. The plot is spoon-fed, and it's not exciting in any way. Just tell me who dunnit already. Some parts seem to move especially slowly.  The 'ethical' choices you face are likewise poorly thought out. In no case do you feel you are in any real danger. In no case can your mistaken judgement hurt people you care about. In the few instances in which your decision could lead to someone's death, it's not someone you really know. It doesn't feel like your gameplay matters much at all.  Compare it to Walking Dead, where so many of your choices have gut-wrenching consequences, and this game is especially disappointing.  It also feels somewhat short.  All in all, it's a good demonstration of what Telltale Games can accomplish (and of course they accomplished it incredibly well in Walking Dead), but it offers a mediocre gaming experience. It would have been better as a short animated series, or even a feature film, than a video game.

Just finished 4 episodes (as of this writing, the 5th is not out yet). This is definitely one of the best adventure games I've ever played. Really amazingly well-done story, fantastic voice acting and some of the most gorgeous graphics I've ever seen, and the setting--a mix of modern-day noire and children's fables in a dark and very adult murder mystery--is engrossing. But the best part of the game is the way that every choice matters, and shapes the story. More games should be like this. My only qualm with the game is the quicktime-event combat. True, the cinematic nature of the combat is cool, but it's hard to pay attention to it when you're constantly looking for the next hotspot you'll have to click or key you'll have to punch. But that's a small price to pay for what is otherwise an outstanding game.

I enjoyed this game a lot, mainly for the art and story. However, I don't feel that I was presented with many choices that mattered. In many ways, it felt like a 'tunnel' adventure game.   You click on the things it tells you to click on, when someone throws something at you, you click on it at the right time and Bigby will knock it out of the way, and when someone pushes you against a wall, you spam 'Q' fast enough and Bigby will push them back. The mechanics of the game are superfluous - almost to the point of being insulting.  But the story and art are wonderful. The game has a lot of atmosphere and character. The people you meet and interact with are interesting and their stories are complex. Just be aware that most decisions are 'damned if you do, damned if you don't'. Once you realize this, you can just kick back and pick random choices, eat popcorn, and watch it unfold like a movie, and don't worry that you didn't pick the right choice - there never was one.  Overall, I'd give it a 6/10. Worth a buy, but catch it on sale.

Yes, I recommend this game, so far at least, with some reservations. Story and characters are well written and voice acting was sharp and well cast. However, long unnatural pauses and some poor interactive game mechanics make me less than thrilled to recommend this one. The pacing just seemed a bit off, which is a shame, because the Walking Dead series from Telltale games has been so excellent and continues to be with the second installment. But I did enjoy the gritty take on the fairy tale characters we all know, and maybe a few we don't, which most have no real resemblance to the originals at all and makes for an interesting hook. It certainly has me wanting to play the rest of the series to see what other fables will get the 'pulp fiction' treatment. Never read the Fables comics this game is based on, so I am unfamiliar with this particular universe as many who play may already be. It certainly isn't necessary to enjoy the game though. Putting aside some minor but annoying flaws, I am enjoying it so far and look forward to the next episodes as they become available. 8/10

This game is ♥♥♥♥ing brilliant, can I say that on here, brilliant? Good. The team at Telltale Games took everything that was right with the walking dead and then Improved on it. Sure it is in ways a visual novel and your only involvement in the story are QTE's, but they are done so well and the story carries such a pace most players wont mind it. The graphics are a bit sharper than the walking dead and it seems as though the texture quality has improved as well. They added pop-ups to the top of the screen indicating how the characters reacted to your choices and that they will remember it in the future so you know exactly where your decisions are coming into play. As far as the story goes the writers have done a unique take on tales we all know and love from when we were kids, you play as Bigby (Big B, Big Bad Wolf) who is a cop in a town full of 'fables' characters from well...fables. Only in his town things get a little mature, don't be surprised to see lots of blood, violence, swearing, alcohol and nudity. Bigby is attempting to solve a crime when he is seemingly dragged into the criminal underworld and left to fend for himself. There may not be an emotional attachment like Clementine (Walking Dead) right off, but the story is good enough that it keeps you interestead through the first episode and definitely left me wanting more. Worth every penny of the $25 price tag.   TL:DR Buy the game.
The universe, characters and story are very compelling and Telltale did an awesome job with the first Episode!

Stays very true to the comics while keeping TellTales signature mark, the best summary I can make of it, is that it is if the comic book itself has come to life. Voice acting is spot on, plenty of intense moments, and great story of the whimsical tales we all know and love but with a dark side and a twist of modern day problems but for Fables.

Too long didn't read: It's fun and I recommend it.   I sat down with the game without reading any reviews or watching any gameplay or anything. Thats usually how I like my games, a fresh point of view.  Game is very solid, nice story line and like most telltale games you have a nice impact on the story. It came off more as if I changed the story and lets say The Walking Dead series.  Combat was alright, although its filled with quicktime events. I rarely like this, but in these types of games its more like watching a movie where you press buttons occasionally.   The game was not perfect by any means, since I did encounter a couple of bugs. Sometimes they were funny though.  For example at the end of the game when I was going to see Snow, I was just a pair of floating teeth. Or another time, all the speech options were filled with 'This option is blank', when I pressed the button anyways I teleported around in the story sometimes going forward sometimes backwards. Got me ♥♥♥♥ing confused.  Easy fix though, just reboot the game and start from latest checkpoint.  The only real problem I had with the game was the intro scene every time I finished an episode. Its not a big problem or anything, but it was kinda annoying having to watch Bigby's silhouette walk for 2 minutes every time I felt like playing multiple episodes.   It was a really nice story though, you can be a real sack of ♥♥♥♥ at times, just the way I like it.  7/10 - Would play again in a year or two. Maybe as a nice guy that time.

Telltale games, a relatively unknown game studio for most of its life, has recently hit it big since releasing its Walking Dead titled adventure game released last year. A studio previously known for comedic-styled adventure games, the Walking Dead was a huge change of direction for the studio. It incorporated a gritty comic book style art style, with mature themes and the possibility for you the player to make the choices. Telltale continues along this path with their newest game: The Wolf Among Us.  Set in the same world as the comic book series “Fables”, The Wolf Among Us brings us the story of Bigby, AKA, the big bad wolf. Him, along with most of our other beloved story book characters, have been forced out of their homelands and have had to relocate to New York City and live their lives secretly under the guise of regular people. Don’t let the storybook references fool you however, as this is not a game for children. The Wolf Among Us tackles some mature subject matter, specifically a murder case, and includes some graphic scenes and crude language among other things.  The Wolf Among Us draws from its source material well, as it delivers an extremely intriguing story full of interesting characters and innovate locales. You are constantly on your toes as the action pulls you to various crime scenes and other locations. Bigby is a likeable main character, gruff and straight to the point, but vulnerable in ways that only you the character really understand.  As an adventure game, it follows the classic point and click formula; talking to people, collecting items, and exploring the environment as your main tasks. While some people will dislike the lack of action in the game, it really gives you a more emotional attachment to the story and characters, which makes the moments of action (through quick time events) that much more dramatic. Being able to make decisions and choose conversation responses as Bigby really drew me into the game, giving me a sense of purpose and feeling like my decisions really mattered. The game specifically presents two large choices that you will have to pick from, and whichever you pick can drastically alter your game experience.  Like most other Telltale games before it, The Wolf Among Us is being released in an episodic format akin to a television show. Meaning after finishing the roughly two hour long episode you will be aggravated to find you have to wait for the next. The cliffhanger ending definitely added suspense and I found myself eagerly awaiting the next episode.  The Wolf Among Us is a brilliant adventure game, and one of Telltales best. Its great story, interesting art style, and memorable characters leave me eagerly awaiting the release of the next episode.
For those who like the Fables graphic novels, I recomend this game.

Very enjoyable experience. Another Telltale Games masterpiece. I can't wait for the next episode. I thoroughly enjoy the element of suspense created by not knowing which characters are going to make it.  I wish they would release episodes faster, but that is also part of what makes Telltale games so great; you can really tell that they are taking the information gathered from players experiences to help craft the experience the best way possible.  A lot of people do not like QTEs. however, the ones you will encounter are very well done and will have you excited rather than annoyed and frustrated.  I really can't think of much negative criticism. Easily 9/10.

This game has potential. Amazing setting and plot, charismatic characters, splendid graphics. But that's not a movie we're talking about, we are dealing with a videogame. I already knew it wouldn't have traditional mechanics and that's fine, I liked it the way it is; but after finishing the first episode and playing it a second time, just to see how choices I made mattered, it left me quite disappointed. Every dialogue ends the same no matter what I do, and the highlighted choices of the player only change few minor sequences during scenes; I didn't bought it for QTE, you know. I would understand if the linearity of Episode One was due to setting and character introductions, but I hope the future releases will make me feel more like I'm affecting the storyline, because this game deserves to be perfect.  Nonetheless, I really enjoyed this game and I'm looking forward to play the rest of it. My complaint does not change the fact it's a good work, I just think it can be bettered. C'mon TellTale, do your best! Don't stick on a mere eight-out-of-ten!  Hope my review was useful! Thanks for reading.  Stefano Giancristofaro

This is an absolutely brilliant game.  It can, of course, be compared to The Walking Dead, but its tone is different. The lack of zombies makes it less... gory and gross and more just socially engaging. Whenever The Walking Dead made me open a door, I remember thinking 'What will jump me from behind there?'. Here, it's a little more subtle, more like 'Now what will these people want me to do?'.  You will have to make moral decisions and these will have an impact on how people behave around you. No, it will not alter the story completely in a huge way, certain milestones have to be touched.  What makes the story great is how they implemented the fairytale creatures, how everyone ended up. To me, not having read the comics, that was interesting to see. The whole issue of blending in with the humans and the kind of society this creates is awesome. (Seriously, Sheriff Bigby Wolf... how cool is that?) That, added to the decision-making of the Telltale Engine, makes for one of the best games ever made.

The Wolf Among us is another great Telltale 'interactive movie' game. Your time is spent watching more than playing but when the story and characters are so good you don't mind. It probably helps that I'm a big fan of the Fables comic on which this game is based.

This is one of my favorite games of all time. For those who aren't aware, it revolves around a bunch of different fairy-tale characters called Fables, such as Snow White, Ichabod Crane, The Little Mermaid, and most importantly, the Big Bad Wolf. The game is tailored by the choices you make, and your decisions can lead to good or bad things later down the road, as I'm sure most of you who have played Telltale games before already know.   The reason I loved this game so much is because it takes a bunch of fairy-tale characters that you already know and puts them all together in this dark, grimy story, and it's really interesting to see it all. That's also the reason I enjoyed this more than The Walking Dead; the setting was just overall more appealing to me, and I really liked The Walking Dead, so if you're like me, you will love this game.  Overall, the story is excellent and the only real complaint I have is one I have also had with The Walking Dead, and that is the fact that some of the dialogue choices aren't clear whether they are going to be nice or mean, and you might end up picking something thinking it's going to be one thing and really it's the other. The dialogue can also be iffy at times, but it doesn't take away from the story whatsoever, just a small annoyance. I really love this game, and I recommend it to anyone who appreciates Telltale games and dark, fairy-tale stories.

A fantastic first episode sets up an interesting murder mystery filled with difficult choices, great characters and a unique fairytale-meets-noir setting. Worth the time to check out, especially if you enjoyed The Walking Dead.

BUY IT.

I can't say enough good things about this game. This is the first 'episode based interactive drama game' I've tried, and I have to say, I'm a big fan.  The games is based on the amazing comic-book series 'Fables' and is a prequel to the series. The story line and feel to the game is very much in keeping with the series, but you don't need any knowledge of this to enjoy the game. Back story is provided as you play through.  The game itself is superbly made, boasting great voice-acting, artwork work, music (a great 80's throwback soundtrack) and storyline that combine to make the game really engaging. The game combines conversation trees with more action-orientated scenes (where you have to make real time decisions and interact with the characters more) to guide players through a world where you do feel like the choices you make influence the outcome and storyline. I'm a relatively casual gamer, and I hardly ever replay games, but with TWAU, I've found myself replaying episodes to a) see what other storylines I can uncover and b) to simply play more of the game. Telltale has also built in a statistics tracker, so that at the end of epsiodes, it compares your choices on major deicisons to that of other players. Quite neat relly.   If you are looking for a fast paced game, then this isn't for you. The game has it's moments of drama, but the draw of the game is the storyline and characters, rather than the actual gameplay. It's like watching a beautifully drawing animated movie, where you have to power to influence how it ends.

I love the art style, it just looks so beautiful and straight out of a comic book.  My only complaint would be about the gameplay. Moving with WASD is a bit clunky and the camera is really restrictive. Those are only minor complaints however, and I just can't wait for the final chapter to come out.

A gripping story, engaging choices, and well-executed action scenes made for the most enjoyable Telltale adventure yet, and that makes for high praise. As someone who has read the comic series, this game makes me ache for further stories from that world.  In terms of value, the entire adventure took me around ten hours; there's no way to skip dialogue or fast forward through scenes. Though this might sound onerous, it helps to add to the cinematic atmosphere they're trying to achieve. The game has many individual choices that can influence later events, some large, some small, and the way the save-system works encourages entire run-throughs. With that being said, I can fully imagine another ten hours spent on this game in the future. Most certainly worth your time and money, on sale or off.

Got this game because I was a fan of the Fable comics. It has made me a fan of Tell-Tale games. Excellent story telling and character interactions. Despite the fact that I usually hate quick time events it works for this style of game and was well implimented. Be warned the game surprises you sometimes with events so best be ready. My only big complaint is the timer being to quick when choosing what to say. I am somewhat indesisive and had to start Episode One over again because of one too many times Bigby just said nothing. A lesser complaint is the proper thing to do is a bit obscure at times, but not so often or extremely as it takes away from the overall game. Plus in trying to figure what random bit to look at gave me lots of other fun tid-bits. Lastly the thing i found strangely funny about the game is how often Bigby messes with the crime scene. Some are options, but if the character has the option of touching blood I am going to take that option. It is too weird not to.

I didn't enjoy The Wolf Among Us nearly as much as I did the first season of The Walking Dead, but I suppose that's not a reasonble bar to set. 'Wolf' is a very different sort of story: a noir murder mystery rather than the horror of man's inuhmanity to man. Unfortuantely, even taking that into account, the overall product feels much weaker.  That's not to say that Wolf is bad, exactly. I enjoyed it as often as not. That just means that about half the time I wasn't particularly engaged, either. I think there's some interesting characters here, they just don't always have interesting things to do. For every time that the plot moves in a really interesting direction, it also sort of plods off on some weird tangent that neither builds tension nor moves things forward. The action scenes sometimes look REALLY cool... and sometimes are overly long and very tedious.  I wouldn't recommend it to everyone, but if you're interested in a relatively by-the-numbers noir murder mystery framed in an interesting setting, it could be for you. The 25 dollar price tag may fit the production value of the game (which, as you might expect with TellTale, is top notch), but the quality of the story and gameplay may fall a bit under that.

The Wolf Among Us has an incredible story, and if you've played the walking dead you should know that your choices have a greater affect than just dialogue. It'll keep you on the edge of your seat the whole time (in a good way) and craving more of it; it's a hard game to put down. It's always surprising and keeps you guessing, and the ending was pretty damn satisfying (although a little bit of a cliffhanger). I seriously recommend this game for anyone who likes Telltale's style of gaming, and even to those who don't.

I thoughly enjoyed this game! Not only is it rich in story, but it overlaps throughout the playthough (which I find important with a good narrative). I love the idea of using fables in a modern, slum like outcome. The style it is drawn out - almost like a comic book - makes it fun and not too realistic (if violence is a problem for you). The choices you make effects the entire game, and I love the level of control. It is not a difficult game for anyone who struggles with constant key movement and directions. I am very excited to finish The Wolf Among Us and play The Walking dead season 2.
This game has a place in my heart that wil never be replaced.

this game ♥♥♥♥ed me up but I love it and it was worth every cent and then some.

When it comes to telling an interesting an engaging story, Telltale sure know hows to do it. If you're looking for something to keep you busy while waiting for the next episode of The Walking Dead Season 2, or you're just looking for an entertaining, cinematic experience, The Wolf Among Us is the game for you.  Meet a whole cast of interesting characters, all named/inspired from popular fairy tales, stories, and even nursery rhymes such as Georgie Porgie, Snow White, Tweedle Dee and Tweedle Dum, and even the Big Bad Wolf himself. Just when things begin to get somewhat dull, you're pulled right into the action with new twists, turns, characters, and more.  A world of fairy tale characters solving a murder case in modern day New York is something that would otherwise sound crazy or downright idiotic. Yet somehow Telltale Games pulls it off with another great game that is worth a spot in any Steam library.
This is an amazing graphic adventure game. I really enjoyed the episodes that are out now and i hope Telltale keep producing this game. I would pay for a seaon 2! Just play it, it's awesome!
If you aren't a fan of Fables, you soon will be. If you are, why haven't you gotten this game yet?

Based off of Fables, an award winning comic series, comes a dark and gritty perspective of popular fairy tale characters struggling to surive in reality, the days of living 'happily ever after' have passed. Deep within New York City, a secluded community known as Fabletown, numerous fairy tale characters guard their presence from the mundane world through the use of magic devices called glamours which cloaks their true identities. Murder has struck the community leaving one citizen dead. Hunt for the killer as Fabletown's sheriff Bigby, the big bad wolf. As you delve into the investigation, you'll swiftly discover that the roots of the murder stretch farther down into the underworld of Fabletown than originally anticipated. Following your quarry's trail, you'll interact with your favourite fables and dig into the community's lore. In this game, your decisions shape the world around you and impact your overall experience. Take hold of the reigns, determine the outcomes, and play the way that you wish. What will you do?
Telltale sure knows how to tell a story. And damn is this a good one.

A truly amazing game!  Anybody who enjoys the point and click genre and even those who don't (you can use a pad ffs) should play this game. The guys who made Walking Dead have smashed it again with this game. A truly mature storyline with some morally grey choices to make you stay up at night wondering if you've done the right thing.  Oh and you get to play as a wolf!  9.5/10

Brilliant story set in the Fables Comics, during the first comic story arc. The atmosphere is excellently conveyed - creating an air of fantasy tinged detective noir. The art is brilliant, and the characters together with the dialogue make the story mysterious and involving. One never knows where a choice will lead you, but from the previous Telltale Games creations, I have learnt that my choices are simply that...choices. Right or wrong, I just ride with the story, and accept the consequences. That's life...and the game is sooooo good at making it feel like you are Bigby Wolf...powerful, but lost in the intricacy of the crimes. Mistrusted for being a villain in the past, Bigby tries hard (or not :-)) to overcome the stigma of his past. Awsome!!! The only critisism is that the game finished all too soon. I want more!!!

What can I say? This is a fine product. Is it worth you money? That depends on a couple of things. If you're looking at the reviews of this game, you probably already know what kind of game it is. We're talking point-and-click adventure. But really, it's something more than that. It's a graphical adventure with point-and-click elements. Just buy it. Play it. You'll enjoy it.   9/10.

Truly one of the greatest games I've played this year. The story and characters are rich and compelling, and the art style is unique and perfectly suited to the gritty action. The music underlines everything perfectly and draws it together. 10/10.
This game is more of a personality simulator, there always seems to be four types of choices. Nice, Neutral, A**hole, and silence. Other than that the game is wonderful in every way.
Easily one of my favorite games. Epic story, the choices matter, great art style, voice acting...  Totally recommend.

Telltale decided to make a fairytale with hookers, drugs, profanity and violence. The Wolf Among Us is the result. The game is more of an interactive story than a puzzler or exploration based point-n-click, but it has a killer (ha ha) plot featuring some great characters with persistent reactions to your choices. The noir-feel fits well with the premise of playing the sheriff on a murder case, but the strong narrative focus means you’ll, sadly, nearly always be a spectator to the actual sleuthing. Play this for the story.

Telltale has spent years perfecting the art of storytelling. 2012's The Walking Dead seemed like they had reached an apex, and the only way to go was down. Lucky for us, Telltale managed to climb a little bit higher with The Wolf Among Us. Set in the iconic Fabletown of Bill Willingham's phenominal comic series, you play as Bigby Wolf (The Big Bad Wolf), as he tries to solve a series of gruesome murders. The atmosphere is dark, moody, and mature. The tone that is set by the art direction pays a deep and loving homage to such noir classics as The Maltese Falcon and Chinatown. The game's story is riveting and engaging, and the choices that are presented to the player feel like they matter! As Bigby Wolf, you feel like every decision you make has a deep impact on the lives of the other fables . . . and often, those decisions are tough to make! The Wolf Among Us has the look, the feel, and the narrative to come of the heels of The Walking Dead and not only hold its own, but shine in the process!  9.5/10
Honestly, if you haven't got this game or any other telltale series, then you don't deserve a spot on my friends list. Jus kidding but seriously, get it.
Highly recommened - if you like cinematic adventures with good characters, a great story and a lot of swearing then get this game. 9/10
Interesting characters and tough choices, I love the way the conversations play out in this interactive noir story.
You punch fairytale characters in the face a lot. Great game, love the story and setting.
Awesome game, can't wait until Chapter 4.

The graphic style and ambient music really contribute to the fantastic atmosphere, fantastic voice acting, enjoyable characters, this is an excellent film noir style point and click adventure, set in a familar but twisted fairly tale world. Up to season 3 so far, each season builds on the last. Absoutly loving it,  If you liked the walking dead, and enjoy a film noir, this is a must play.  Highly recommended.

First of all thank you TellTale for creating this emersive and wonderfull experience . I enjoyed each and every moment of this game and been on the edge of my seat for the last few hours. All in all I enjoyed this game immensly for the grippiung story and realy hope this Franchise gets another game.
I huffed, I puffed, and it blew my mind; worth every penny 5 times over.
Amazing game so far. Must play. Especially if you played the walking dead
I really enjoyed this game I would and have recommended it.

The Wolf Among us is thought provoking to say the least from both its source material and TellTales experience at story telling. If you enjoyed storytelling and characters that actually have a real personality pick this one up.
I really liked the storyline and am on the second run of the game. The only down side is that sometimes the time to select what you want to say is too quick for me to read all the options trought.

Not as good (IMO) as Walking Dead, but recommend for fans of TWD.  TWAU is a modern-fantasy mystery game. The entire premise is that you're a private detective of sorts, investigating a series of gruesome killings.  The twist is that you're THE 'Big Bad Wolf', and the victims are all other supernatural creatures, who are all hiding in 1980's New York City.  The premise is definitely interesting, and does allow for some fantastic storytelling and characters, but if you're expecting something as emotional and impactful as TWD, you'll be a little dissapointed, at least so far (only 2 episodes out so far as I write this).

One of the best games I've played recently, The setting is amazing and the story is very interesting. It felt a little slow in the beginning but at the end of the first episode i was really hooked, Can't wait for episode 3!

To be honest, The Wolf Among Us is one of the best games which I've ever played. I can't understand people who play it only once cuz even at the end this game leaves you with a lot of questions. Even at the end you ask yourself WHAT THE ♥♥♥♥KKKKK. This game gives you an opportunity to create your own story, to create your own Big Bad Wolf. Wolf Among Us was pretty captivating from the start. The characters are unique. The gameplay stands out from other adventure games. It's story-driven, choice-driven, and outcomes carry over into later parts of the episode.  I would definitely recommend this game. However, waiting for new episode releases is mind-numbing. We've waited 4 months for another 2 - 3 hours of gameplay. If this wait time is typical for this title, we will be well into next year by the time episode 5 finally rolls around.

I bought this on sale as I'd had mixed experiences with Telltale stuff before - it was totally worth full price. It all works beautifully with a gorgeous look, thrilling story and great acting - and plenty of choices adding replay value.

I think everything has been said about this game already but I'll throw a couple pennies in.  Point n Click adventure that is quite simply AMAZING!  Based off of the DC/Vertigo Comic books F.A.B.L.E.S, you are the sherrif in town: Bigby Wolf (aka The Big Bad Wolf). You police a town in New York called Fable Town which is run by Old King Cole (was a merry old soul...) and his right hand Snow White. Most of the FABLES went to live in Fable Town, assuming that they were either human looking or close to human. Anyone who wasn't (Puss in Boots, 3 Little Pigs, The 3 Bears etc) went to live on an upstate Farm called 'The Farm'. Bigby is not allowed on the Farm for obvious reasons, so having no where to put him, King Cole and Snow White made him the Sherrif of Fable Town.  This game follows one of many cases that Bigby has had to deal with.  It should also be noted that this game is set BEFORE the comic books. So although it is not necessary to read them to understand this game, I would still recommend that you pick up the graphic novels at some point as they are every bit as awesome as the game is....just...be kind to Colin...he falls on hard time in the comics ;-)  Pros: -Great Sound Track -Great Acting -Great Visual -Great Story  Cons: -QTE's but on some occasions, these are a necessary evil  What I would like to see improved in the next season: -More puzzles -More opportunities to use detective skills, allow the user to miss things etc  Can't wait for Season 2. Hopefully they bring in Rose Red and Goldilocks (loved what they did with those characters in the comic books)
GOOD GAME 10/10 I WANT MOOOAR !

A quality game. Though it is a tad light on content (less than two hours per chapter) it reveals just enough about Fables to keep everything moving. The game is very defensive about this being made for 'mature' audiences. Below is a portion of the Q&A from their website:  The Wolf Among Us is about fairytale characters and creatures? It’s for kids, right? Absolutely not. The Wolf Among Us, like the Fables comic books it’s based on is a mature experience. It is violent and gritty and deals with adult themes. These are not the characters and stories from sanitized animated movies; they’re bloody, sexy and have never been on the side of a child’s lunchbox.  Calm down TT, we get it. You want to be taken seriously. Will it help when some of the rough edges are smoothed? Of course. Until then, most players will take the game as it is. What is it? The first real step of the graphic novel that can create a stepping stone for other games. The Walking Dead is great, but it comes with the name. Stick it on most anything done half well and some money can be made. This shows that all the success wasn't just from the flash hit. What propelled this type of game to new heights was the form itself.
Once again telltale delivers an exceptional story with hard decisions and characters you truly care about. Exceeded my High expectations that I had aquired from previous games.

I was slightly disappointed by Act 5 - I was hoping for more consequences of my earlier actions, a number of threads remain unresolved, and the 'courtroom' scene was stiff and the weakest part of the whole series... but even with those faults it was an enjoyable episode.  But all that said, it is a fantastic choose your own adventure game and the world of Fables is one I would like to visit more frequently. A worthwhile purchase.

The game manages to keep you focused on it, without being too intense. I was completely immersed in the story immediately, even though I don't particularly like all the cliches they added to the story. But it's all part of the experience and it feels very natural.

The Wolf Amomg us is a lot like Telltale's the Walking Dead. It a detective noir theme rather than a survival theme, as you basically play a sherrif investigating a conspiracy. It also takes place in a setting in which fables are real and are hiding out in a secret community in new york city. I personally found this to be really unique and refreshing, especially compared to Walking Dead's zombie apocalypse setting.   There are a few other key differences as well. Instead of choices being about who lives or dies, it's more about moral ambiguity. You will have to make a lot of really hard decisions with no clear right answer. Yes, in some cases it's as simply as do you kill this person or not, but like I said it's morally ambiguous.   One problem with this game is that there are too many characters that are totally unlikable. In fact, there was only a few characters in the entire cast that I didn't hate. It's really hard for a game to be morally ambiguous when everyone is constantly being a jerk. It broke the immersion somewhat but it wasn't too bad in my opinion.   This game as a really complex and interesting story though with a lot of twists and turns. It's excellently paced, the dialouge is well-written, and the voice-acting is top notch. I think this is the most reedming feature of the game. I was hooked and couldn't stop playing, I ended up playing all 5 episodes in one sitting. It was that good. It really sucks you in and makes you have to know what happens next.   When you combine all these features, The Wolf Among Us feels to me like the ultimate evoloution of storytelling games.   Take note that this game is a lot more adult than Walking Dead as well. There is constant cussing, A LOT of violence and gore, and plenty of adult themes.   If you like detective noir, storytelling games, and tough decisions, this game is for you.

It's been a while ever since I couldn't wait to hear the ending, and this game got me waiting on the edge of my seat with each choice I made. When a game has you contemplating over every decision, where your morals and conscience are in play, you know it was done right.

Highy recommended!  Unique style, strong voice acting, a friendly and forgiving user experience, an engaging storyline - The Wolf Among Us has all of it.  Less ponderous than The Walking Dead, the universe presented in The Wolf Among Us benefits from being easy to digest. The characters are steeped in both the comic's source material and from the fairy tales where Bigby and company originate. Because we can immediately place Snow, Ichabod and the Woodsman, there's no need to waste time on exposition. I don't think that was lost on the developers and it makes for a richer story.  And it is a good story! The writers keep things moving at a brisk pace, and it does keep you guessing. Your choices and their consequences however are a bit more ambiguous in this than the Walking Dead. And that's fine too, Fabletown is rife with moral ambiguity, so it fits.  Of middling concern is that It's not a terribly long game - but then again, it's not $60. On sale, as it is frequently, it's a bargain. it's about as good as can be made with TellTale's tech.  So, if you've got a few hours to kill and you want to be told a good tale, this is it.  But be nice to TJ woudja? He's just adorable, that little guy.

I don't know much of what can be said about The Wolf Among Us that hasn't been said by a lot of people. I will start by saying that I strongly recommend this game to 'most' gamers. Hardcore and Not so Hardcore alike. There are a few I know who wouldn't like the game for it's content.  Overall: Let me start off by saying this review is spoiler free. First, I almost didn't get this game, the subject matter, modern new york noir crime is NOT my thing. Yet, I got it on a deal with the recommendation of my friend. And I was blown away by the game.  Presentation: Gone are the extra frills you come to expect in most games, invintory puzzles, extra treasure hunts, pointless wander and collect. This game is liniar in the way a liniar game should be. The way of a storyteller. It uses strong nerrative, powerful and interesting backstories, combined with wonderful voice acting to create an immersive experiance that will make the time you spend on it blow by way too fast. It's short, but it's replayable much like your favorate movie of all time would be. Time flies when you're having fun and you WILL have fun.  Warnings: Next is my obligatory content warning, Blood and Gore, Violence, Violence towards women (Not you), Cussing, Nudity. Things that normally repel me. While this stuff still repels me and almost stopped me from buying the game, it was executed tastefully for the sake of the story, every drop of blood has a purpose, every violent action has a reason, rather you know it, or figure it out or not. The cussing is executed naturally, though rather gratuatously. And the brief bits of nudity were not overly highlighted and ended up adding to the atmosphere. Would I let a kid play it? HELL NO!  Lore Nut: As a fan of comics, as a fan of the Grimm Fairy tales, this was told from a more origional book context that a lot of the retellings that were watered down for kids of our generation. Some tales had insinuated incest (attempts at least), grim details, blood. To be honest, I think the kids of the era grim wrote sort of grew up on the Noir of their era.  The Badass: There were tons of badass moments throughout the game, from the first punch swung in the first chapter to the climactic boss battles, to the way Bigby Wolf even acts, he is an honest to god badass in ever sense of the word. No matter how tame you play him to be, he is one dangerous person, and someone you would not want on your badside.  Unique Aspect: The draw to people normally not of the subject matter. My sister for instance came over and I talked her into playing it. She despises cussing more than I do, despises new york's setting, hates gore, and abhors cussing. And she was caught into the storyline, the characters interested her, and I could tell some of them pushed her buttons, but never enough to cause her to set the game down.  Who shouldn't pick up the game: People who don't play games for stories. People who have small children watching over their shoulder every moment they game. People who play games for collecting, to waste time, grind hounds, or people simply wanting their next headshot.  Who should play this game: Everyone else. People who said to themselves: I'd love to play an interactive movie. Fable comic fanatics. People who love solving problems or using logic, but not wanting to have to use a spreadsheet... YOU! Yes, You who's sitting in your chair after reading the who shouldn't list and saying to yourself: That doesn't describe me at all. Hell, I even recomend this game to people who normally don't like the grittiness as long as they're willing to enter it with an opened mind and try something new.

'Wolf Among Us' is a lovely counterpart to those already familiar with the FABLES universe, or a decent introduction to it for those who are simply looking for a good, story driven game.  The art design is lovely, remaining true to the story's roots in comic form. It has the 2D look in a 3D format, reminiscent of the Borderlands series, thought with a slightly different stylistic spin. Familiar and new characters abound, the story is solid, engaging and full of sufficient misdirection to keep the mystery interesting, and the game boasts some of the best voice acting I have ever heard.  The drawbacks are few, but depending on the player, these could be smaller or larger irritants.   Achievements are almost nonexistent and consist only of character/place/information unlocks and chapter completeions.  More significantly, he points at which the player takes physical control of Bigby's movements can be a bit awkward; I've never been a fan of straight up WASD movement controls (no mouse involvement). Fighting mechanics are extremely simplistic, consisting of random direction dodging, mouse clicks on targetted areas and fillling up a strength bar through keymashing. As these aspects are not the larger focus of the game, I have a great deal of forgiveness for it, even though Bigby took quite a few unnecessary punches due to unclear timing while I was in the driver's seat. In my opinion, the graphic style, plot and voice acting made up more than admirably for any wonky mini fights/detection scenarios.  I can't speak to the replayability of the game at this time, but would seem to be enough alternate choices that it could well warrant 2 or more additional runs of the campaign.  A hearty thumbs up for a visually pleasing game. Great characters, excellent story, well put together. A perfect tie-in to an Eisner award winning title.

Fairytale characters are living in a district in New York. They have to be incognito, which they achieve by magic making them appear like ordinary humans. You're playing as the Big Bad Wolf, who is the sheriff.   Like the Walking Dead episodes, this is more an interactive movie than a game. You get timed (and a handful of non-timed) decisions and quick-time events.  The story contains a speaking frog and pig and well-known fairytale to urban legend characters like snow white, the big bad wolf and the woodsman from the red riding hood tale or tweedle dee & dum. the story is quite graphic - for example you see a head that has been chopped of its body, an axe that hits into the back of a head, blood trails and sometimes you have the free decision to kill someone.  Altogether it's a fairytale noir. Highly recommended for the story, not neccessarily for the 'game'play.

The Wolf Among Us is another brilliant experience from Telltale Games. For everyone that doesn't know, the story is based on the Fables series of comics written by Bill Willingham. You play as one of the main characters from the comics, Bigby Wolf. Once known as the Big Bad Wolf, Bigby is the sheriff of Fabletown which is a part of New York City where the Fables reside.  The story starts with a simple noise complaint from Toad and progresses as events in Fabletown spiral out of control. Fables who don't have natural human forms have to purchase glamours to make them appear as humans. Any non-human Fable who doesn't is sent to a rural community known as 'The Farm'. The end of the game, which is the 1st season, leaves you in a cliffhanger situation which will make you instantly want to play the next game.  The games uses the same point-and-click system as the Walking Dead games from Telltale Games. The player can chose what Bigby says and does during conversations and can explore areas that they're in. The combat system, which is mainly quick time events, involves the use of the wasd keys, repeatedly tapping q and, obviously, pointing and clicking.  The combination of involved gameplay and an interesting story really make this game stand out. I really enjoyed it and I recommend it. If you liked the Walking Dead games or you have an interest in the murder mystery genre, you'll also enjoy this game.  +Great Story +Amazing Voice Acting +Good Combat System +Attractive Art Style +Fun Gameplay  9/10  Side Note - The game doesn't use many resourses. I ran it on an AMD E-450 notebook which was connected to a 1080p monitor. It ran at over 30fps on 720p with maxed out settings. I recommend running the game with textures set to high to make some parts readable. If you have textures set too low then you won't be able to read text in certain areas.

This is one of my favorite games of all time. For those who aren't aware, it revolves around a bunch of different fairy-tale characters called Fables, such as Snow White, Ichabod Crane, The Little Mermaid, and most importantly, the Big Bad Wolf. The game is tailored by the choices you make, and your decisions can lead to good or bad things later down the road, as I'm sure most of you who have played Telltale games before already know.   The reason I loved this game so much is because it takes a bunch of fairy-tale characters that you already know and puts them all together in this dark, grimy story, and it's really interesting to see it all. That's also the reason I enjoyed this more than The Walking Dead; the setting was just overall more appealing to me, and I really liked The Walking Dead, so if you're like me, you will love this game.  Overall, the story is excellent and the only real complaint I have is one I have also had with The Walking Dead, and that is the fact that some of the dialogue choices aren't clear whether they are going to be nice or mean, and you might end up picking something thinking it's going to be one thing and really it's the other. The dialogue can also be iffy at times, but it doesn't take away from the story whatsoever, just a small annoyance. I really love this game, and I recommend it to anyone who appreciates Telltale games and dark, fairy-tale stories.

Become The Big Bad Wolf and help the department solve the crimes within Fabletown. I recomend it!

Overall good sound-track (I love the menu theme), good voice-acting as always, strong dialogues and that are often humorous; better free roam scenes than in The Walking Dead with smoother mouse control and better camera angles; consistent and believable characters, one of which you can shape yourself; better graphics than in The Walking Dead. Also, the world of The Wolf Among Us is way better than The Walking Dead. It's incredibly original and fun to explore. Another main difference between The Walking Dead are the kind of choices you have to make. In The Walking Dead, you choose with the purpose to maximize you chances of survival, whereas in The Wolf Among Us, you do not choose to survive but to unveil the truth as fast as possible. The Walking Dead is more of a survival horror game, whereas The Wolf Among Us is a whodunit.  Episode One: Faith  8/10  Episode Two: Smoke and Mirrors  The second episode primarily focusses on the story, there's only one combat scene and two nice plottwists. I was pleasantly surprised by the variety of scenes in this episode: you being interrogated, you interrogating/torturing, a post-mortem body examination, visiting a brothel, visiting a murder site, etc. The play time is around 2 hours, and could be longer although 10 hours (approx. 5*2) for 20 euros is actually a good deal. Still, the episodic releases do slow the game down and I think you should play all episodes after one another to really feel like you get a 10 hour game.  8/10  Episode Three: A Crooked Mile  Starts off with a blast. Does a good job at keeping introducing characters steadily. Good nuancing of the characters of Bigby and Snow. A rather short episode, slow-paced and focusses on deepening the mystery instead of giving answers or fights. The now habitual fight at the end is not really convincing, but you are presented with one really hard choice. However, when replaying the episode I couldn't help but notice that you have hardly any impact at all on the story, and decisions made in previous episodes are also insignificant for the present. What also struck me was the queer randomness of pop-ups like '... will remember that.' Throwing some dialogue options that merely affects a handful of spoken lines but nothing significant, and adding a pop-up here and there do a good job at creating the feeling the player makes a significant difference, but most of that is sadly an illusion.  7/10  Episode Four: In Sheep's Clothing  8/10  Episode Five: Cry Wolf  Overall, this episode doesn't look very polished. The beginning fight is somewhat choppy and doesn't play very fluent and the background music is also almost non-existant. The acting and voice-acting is also not very convincing especially moments of stress. Bigby's wolf form is not very detailed and the fight with Bloody Mary should be the climax of the episode but isn't really.  At the end of episode four, you had the feeling you didn't know anything, but that doesn't get much better. Although some infractions of the Crooked Man are revealed, you can't really fathom fully what he's about. Bloody Mary also, elaborating on her personality? Nope.  Good to see that the Crooked Man's has some charisma however which makes for an interesting ending scene, and cool that he confronts you with some of your choices, but in the end, it doesn't matter, like most (if not all) choices you make in this game actually.   7/10  All in all a (much) better, more interesting and more original series than The Walking Dead and well worth the price.

I had never heard of the Fable universe before trying out The Wolf Among Us (TWAU). I initially was deterred by a screenshot of an oversized anthropomorphic toad, but I went ahead anyway and I'm glad I did, because TWAU is a well realized and interesting setting of various fairy tale characters trying to build and maintain a community in the ordinary (“real”) world.  You play as the sherif of Fable Town trying to solve a murder mystery. I don't think it is an especially well constructed plot, but it's definitely worthwhile and carried by the atmospheric setting and dialogues. Most of the gameplay consist of dialogue choices, which influence character opinion and behavior, but there aren't major branches in the story – the course is set but you can rock the boat a little left or right along the way. Don't get me wrong however, the storytelling is great and can be emotionally engaging; the game likes to set you up with dilemmas balancing allegiance, restraint and promises between characters.  There are small amounts of QTEs to navigate, but their role is simply to make action sequences seem and feel more interactive. There's no difficulty to anything and no actual puzzle solving required. In that respect TWAU is less of a game and more of an interactive story with player choices adding personal flavour to the protagonist's personality and development.    Strong points  Good storytelling and dialogue Interesting setting, great atmosphere Moral dilemmas   Weak points  Chapters 2 and 4 somewhat lacking Limited replay value Average mystery plot More sightseeing than active player-driven crime solving   Grade B

The Wolf Among Us is a brilliantly told story of what happens before the comic book series. The itself has no spoilers to ruin the comics either if you feel like you would like to know what happens after the game. Telltale Games shows off their trademark player choice system which really affects the story, as the player you can feel the consequence of your choices. I feel the story itself picked up really strong keeping the players lust for next episode(Which there no longer a need to wait for since the game is, for now, complete). However, during the middle of the game I felt the episodes got shorter and could have contained more. I felt like there was not covered, and that there was a lot more room for expansion during the middle episodes. The game's final episodes were to the same standard as the beginning of the series and lived up to the Telltale name. Overall I feel this game is worth buying as it does provide a lot of content which is embedded with player choice/consiquence, very likeable/hateable characters which you can feel a connection to and finally a great in depth story line which holds the playets attention all the way through with replayable capatability as there is much content to cover that you may not see.

Telltale ropes you in with their story and, as always, the first episode is the strongest. From there, you have the QTE, on the spot decisions and each episode has that one or two heavy decisions on what to do. Formulaic Telltale game, but not in the slightest is it boring. The visuals are catching and the story is great. The Wolf Among Us is good for at least two good playthroughs. The only downside to this game is the bug that I, and some others have encountered, where the choices are replaced with 'This Choice Is Blank!' and the game won't play. The only 'fix' is quitting the game and starting up again. While somewhat minor, it could be game breaking to some if they get it, and it is a bit of an annoyance. In any case, I would still recommend this to anyone who is curious or liked The Walking Dead series.

And here we have one more noir adventure. Neo-noir detective with fairy tale elements, to be precise.  In brief, different fabulous characters are exiled from their homelands to our reality. They have to build their new lives here from scratch, disguise their magic nature from common people and somehow get along together despite the conflicts in the past. Don't let the presence of Snow White, Mr. Frog, Bluebeard and other characters from children books mislead you. The story here is rather dark and violent. This world is filled with broken fates, lies, betrayals and grim murders. And it deserves its hero. Hard-boiled sheriff Bigby B. Wolf is constantly torn apart between the role of the rightful protector of his civilians and his own beastly nature which is used to solve all problems by violence. And believe me, even the worst fabulous villains often get heebie jeebies when they see the darker side of the sheriff. And the player in his turn gets his hands shaking.  So you will have to talk, interrogate, gather the evidence, make numerous conclusions and difficult decisions. And, well, break hands, legs, skulls and tear the eyes out. Great!

What do you get when you mix 'down on his luck gumshoe' with the New York Bronx and a bunch of old-world fable beings who are nigh-immortal because actually dying is really hard for them? You get this kind of a setting. You play Bigby Wolf... Aka 'Big B Wolf', aka Big Bad Wolf. He's trying to turn his life around after terrorizing countless fables and mundies and currently the Sherrif of the fables in a Vampire-esque Masquerade to pass as human. And like any detective story, Bigby's day goes bad with a murder.  It's another episodic game from Tell Tale, you get one episode now, and another four as they are released, all five for a single $25 payment. Sorry, no way to get just one episode.  Story: Like The Walking Dead, this is based on a graphic novel, specifically Fables. So expect writing that's already proven itself in another medium.  Gameplay: Limited, admittedly. Point-n-click adventuring mixed in with some quick-time events and a lot of conversations with options. The game keeps track of the choices you've made, and it'll be interesting to see how they affect later episodes.  Graphics: Tell Tale's signature graphic-novel-esque style, tightened a bit from their last foray to cut down on floating lines. Works well with the story.  Audio: The voice acting is top-shelf, and anyone who talks has a voice actor. Special effects are reasonably effective, though there's not much that turns up for a story like this.  Overall, I'd recommend this if you're a fan of adventure games or favor story above detailed gameplay. I know I'm egerly waiting for the next epidoe.

Over all I could'nt have asked for a better execution of this story about fables.

Tl;dr version: Easily one of the best story driven games I have played in a while, deeply satisfying through out. This review is spoiler free.  Many people criticize this game for its choices that have no affect and its bad ending. I can agree to an extent with the choices, but the ending was thoroughly satisfying even though it couldn't be the perfect fairy tale all is well ending everyone wanted, it just wouldn't fit in with the game's style.  Back to the choices. Their are several choices in the game that have a very major impact on the story. People tend to have a huge gripe with the fact not all the choices are like this. I get the argument but not every choice can change the whole landscape of the game. However, once you start stringing small choices together you can see how they are making an impact and it can entirely change how a situation plays out even if it doesn't directly effect the end result.  Though you don't have complete freedom to do whatever you want like many of us would have hoped, it is still satisfying to punch someone in the face for being an ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ instead of having to sit there and watch it play out however the writers decide.  The games story is probably the best in any game from recent memory and has many meaningful twist and turns without being too far-fetched and in the end you get to serve up justice (or not) however you see fit which is incredibly satisfying despite the fact not everyone will agree with your decision.   My only complaint about the game is that it ended and there is no sequel in sight. 9.5/10
Loved this game. It was absolutely worth my money. Interesting story, interesting characters and an original theme (fairy tales) make this one of the best TellTale games ever made.  10/10

There aren't many games that i can say I've played through without a second of being bored, but this is one of those games. 10/10 i sure hope they continue with another season after Episode 5 of Season one, cause its worth it.

The Wolf Among Us is your classic 'who done it' murder mystery. The game takes place in a world where certain characters from your childhood story are brought to life as real people living in a mundane world. As the appointed sheriff of Fabletown, your job is to solve the gruesome death of local fables and bring the perpetrator(s) to justice. The lines between good and bad are blurred. Your decisions carry weight throughout the game. Although not as suspenseful as Telltale Games' The Walking Dead, this game is still worth a playthrough once or twice (good cop/bad cop, especially if you want to unlock all the achievements). Note: In Ep. 4, at the pawn shop, you'll want to look the empty display case last since it is the trigger for the next set of events. Overall: 9/10

This game is basically the same as all modern Telltale games. Choices don't really matter, and are basically just window dressing that servers to alter some dialogue. When it comes to brass tacks, though, the chracters and their reactions will always be the same.   Despite this, The Wolf Among Us is a rarity in it's visual style and it's mixture of unlike elemenets (e.g, a noire visual style with fantasy characters.) The Wolf Among Us basically gathers all of it's strength from its excellent souirce material, while the actual game Telltale delivers is simply servicable.   Bottomline, this game is definetely worth a playthrough, or maybe even a few. The visual style, excellent voice acting, and interesting characters are enough to grab your attention, despite Telltale not changing their formula.
