*Keep in mind, that I'm not that good at speaking English, but I hope it's okay for you.*   EPISODE ONE:  I just finished episode one, and if the game continues that awesome, I'm happy to recommend it to anyone who liked The Walking Dead, but also to all of those, who didn't like the zombie-setting of The Walking Dead. Until now, it tells an adult story about fables, with loads of choices to make (which really DO have consequences!) and loads of violence. It's again more a movie than a game. Furthermore, some fairytales are told further, to say what happend after the 'happily ever after part', and it's not only very human, but still excellently fitting. How cool's that?  EPISODE TWO:  First off, I've had major problems playing this episode. Until I re-installed my entirely PC and played through episode one again, the game always crashed when starting episode two.  With this being said, now to the review itself: I'm somehow torn about this episode. It still is really great written and intense to follow, it's highly enjoyable and the story developes in a very interesting way. There also aren't any cliches, so that's quite good. However, episode two is pretty short. It only took me around one and a half hour to finish it, compared to the two and a half hour I needed for episode one. I have no idea what took them the four months we had to wait for episode two to be released. It still is quite much work, but they promised to not do this, so I hope they also not fail with The Walking Dead Season two, because if they will again, I won't buy their games right at the release of episode one anymore, but wait for the entire product to be released. Don't get me wrong, I still liked episode two really much, and I have nothing against waiting like two months or so for the next episode, but four months is somehow too much.  To sum up: It's a great second episode, though I'd like them to update the game more frequently.  EPISODE THREE: I'm literally suffering right now. Nothing more to say. This episode has been phenominal, more than just outstanding entertainment. I'm writing this while still being affected by the thoughts the ending left me with, so this part of the review is going to be full of emotional nonsense, but I hope that you therefore can see what this game manages to DO to the player.  This is not the shallow crime/romance story you can watch on TV or read in books. This is pure hardcore to decide, both emotional and rational desicions to be made, and the game plays with your feelings. It creates a happy atmosphere, and a few seconds later it dissolves the camouflage and hits you right in the face with terrible desicions you don't ever want to focus in real life. Episode three is, in my opinion, the very best episode of any Telltale game out yet, and I'd highly advise you to buy and play to the game right now if you haven't already. It leaves you breathless, sweating, struggling to control your feelings (for example, I felt a mixture of deep inner pain and aggressiveness, suffer and sadness) and ads a grandiose cliffhanger at the end which will leave you begging for the release of the next episode.  EPISODE FOUR: Take the same as what I wrote for Episode 3, and downgrade it just by a very little. This is how much I liked Episode 4, and also everything I wrote about Episode 3 pretty much applies for Episode 4 aswell. No need to double things.  EPISODE FIVE: I'll keep this as short as possible to get you as excited as possible. This episode has got more drama, more talking, less fighting and a better ending than each episode before. The cliffhanger at the end is great and keeps you guessing what is there to come in Season 2. I wish everyone of you a great time playing this game. I loved it over The Walking Dead Season ONE and Season TWO (even though one episode is missing there), which might also be because of that special setting the fables make for. All both major and minor decisions you made throughout any of the episodes before is taken into account and it all comes together to a great final, able to mess with Breaking Bad, and for me, even win the direct comparison. That's video game history, the way stories should be told. That's entertainment at it's purest. That's 'The Wolf Among Us', one of the most thrilling experiences you'll ever get in your live when it comes to grandious stories and being able to help it evolve. Have fun playing, and happy suffering throughout the intense stages. Thanks for reading. :)

The Wolf Among Us (TWAU) serves as a good introduction to the Fables comic book universe. The strengths of this game lie primarily in the story where we see Bigby Wolf towing the line between doing his job and letting the devils of his nature get the better of him. Less successful is the stripped down gameplay.  LIke most games in the 'adventure' genre, gameplay is composed of multiple choice dialogue options and room investigation with added QTE cut scenes for dramtaic flavour. The dialogue trees are fine but there is a lack of interactivity outside of QTE sequences. The moments were you can walk around a room investigating are few and precious. Although it certainly helps the story ticking along, I would have welcomed the opportunity to explore areas at the players descretion rather than when the plot called for it. This is a fault with the gameplay template set out by the Walking Dead where, being in the midst of a zombie apocalypse, the only opportunities to explore are in barricaded areas, otherwise the player was on a journey and couldn't revisit areas. TWAU revolves around the same few locations most of the time. Some of the rooms you visit are even in the same building.  As for the episodic structure, I bought this game just before the release of episode 5 so I didn't have to wait between episodes and I recommend this strategy for any episodic series. Without regular scheduling any tension from cliffhangers could be forgotten if there is a large gap between episodes.  None of these criticisms break the game however. Though no more than an interactiv-ish movie, it is an entertaining one. The characters are relatable and the story is engaging although lacking in the emotional punch of the Walking Dead. Even if you have no interest in the comics (which I haven't read), TWAU is self-contained enough to stand on it's own four paws without depending on established Fables or fairy tale lore. Of course if you don't know who the Big Bad Wolf or Snow White is, then this game may not be for you.  A good story but lacking in interactivity makes for a lean, digestable, but passive experience.  Obligatory score:  3/5

Another wonderful entry from Telltale Games. This game feels like an interactive graphic novel more than a game but that is part of it's charm. It's stylish and beautiful to look at with a very engaging story. Voice acting is spot on as is the atmosphere and the film noir feeling. You care for the characters who are very well fleshed out. In some ways this game reminds me of the Gabriel Knight series. It has that same mysterious mood with magic and some romance thrown in.  I think my main qualm with this game (and the Walking Dead) is the amount of time you get to make a decision in some instances during dialogue options. I don't even have time to read or hear what is being said when the time to make a decision runs out. Is that really necessary to make the 'decision mechanic' work? Seems more irritating than anything really.

Characters from all fables living in our world, made to look like humans by a magical 'galmour', until the spell has to be renewed. Surprisingly rough&serious ♥♥♥♥ happening. Interesting. Fun.   Great, with 4 more chapters to come (included). And this first episode at least is rather short, roughly 4,5 hours I'd say. Imagine Law & Order merged with all of your favorite fairy tales and that's The Wolf Among Us. Maybe throw in Bourne Identity fight scenes and call it a day.  This game was thrilling to play and I couldn't peel myself away until I completed it. Through strong story-line and character depth you grow to understand what the Fabletown the inhabitants live in is or what they strive for it to be in the least. You relate to some characters while distancing yourself from others, all the while having a basic understanding of their origins - because many of their stories were ones you grew up listening to. I knew I was going to like this game before I bought it with the gruff crime fighting protagonist, but I did not know I was going to enjoy it as thoroughly as I did.
I loved it. Much better than the walking dead storys.
The Wolf Among Us was another Telltale hit out of the adventure game genre ballpark

An excellent follow-up to Telltale's initial season of The Walking Dead, I ended up enjoying The Wolf Among Us more than that series, even if it doesn't hit with the same emotional wallop. Instead we're presented with a murder mystery that is, much like the setting it takes place in, much more than it seems. Especially impressive is the way your choices in the first four chapters heavily impact the tense final half hour in the fifth.  This is not a difficult game, nor is it an especially complex one (in fact it doesn't get much more basic in terms of mechanics - this makes the Sierra and LucasArts adventures of yore seem impossibly dense by comparison). However, it had me enthralled for its entire duration, and in the end, I really can't ask for more than that.

It may not be as climatic as I wanted it to be, but I ran through it twice and saw great differences between my two playthroughs, and it all felt very organic.  Fully recommended. Fantastic game from the makers of the popular 'Walking Dead' games. Personally, I liked this game much better than 'The Walking Dead.' Both titles excel in their story-driven gameplay, but the stories each game tells are very different and give a different gaming experience. Whereas 'TWD' is essentially a story of survival, akin to the genre of horror games, 'The Wolf Among Us' is a mystery story. While there are moments of danger, life and death are no longer the driving force, but rather the player's interest rests in solving the mystery.  Is that mystery engaging? Yes. Yes, it is. The mystery entangles plenty of suspects -- almost everyone in the game is suspect of something at one point or another. And these characters have good qualities as well. The player will probably be torn between wanting to believe in these characters and doubting every word they say. The main character, Bigby Wolf, also undergoes significant development as a character, the exact direction of which depends on the way the player chooses to play the game, of course. But it all results in remarkably engaging story-telling.  The story is set in New York City, and it seemlessly blends all of the well-known fairy tale characters -- as well as some from other kinds of stories such as urban legends -- into a seedy, poverty-wrecked new world of crime and deception. For those who aren't a fan of fairy tales, don't worry because the crime element will give the story an edge. For those who don't like criminal mysteries, don't worry because the fairy tale element will keep things imaginitive.  Lastly, I just have to mention that all of the above make me like the game. It is the animation and the sound that make me love it. The colors, the style, the music -- it's all perfect for what the game is.  I thought I wouldn't like this game, but I'm so glad I gave it a try. I highly recommend that others do the same.

Utterly fantastic game that breaks from the usual genres you might play, and thoroughly grips you with its riveting storyline and gripping (if somewhat slow at times) gameplay. Well worth a play at the price offered on Steam (compared to the rip off on Xbox etc)

The Wolf Among Us is a brilliantly told story of what happens before the comic book series. The itself has no spoilers to ruin the comics either if you feel like you would like to know what happens after the game. Telltale Games shows off their trademark player choice system which really affects the story, as the player you can feel the consequence of your choices. I feel the story itself picked up really strong keeping the players lust for next episode(Which there no longer a need to wait for since the game is, for now, complete). However, during the middle of the game I felt the episodes got shorter and could have contained more. I felt like there was not covered, and that there was a lot more room for expansion during the middle episodes. The game's final episodes were to the same standard as the beginning of the series and lived up to the Telltale name. Overall I feel this game is worth buying as it does provide a lot of content which is embedded with player choice/consiquence, very likeable/hateable characters which you can feel a connection to and finally a great in depth story line which holds the playets attention all the way through with replayable capatability as there is much content to cover that you may not see.

'Wolf Among Us' is a lovely counterpart to those already familiar with the FABLES universe, or a decent introduction to it for those who are simply looking for a good, story driven game.  The art design is lovely, remaining true to the story's roots in comic form. It has the 2D look in a 3D format, reminiscent of the Borderlands series, thought with a slightly different stylistic spin. Familiar and new characters abound, the story is solid, engaging and full of sufficient misdirection to keep the mystery interesting, and the game boasts some of the best voice acting I have ever heard.  The drawbacks are few, but depending on the player, these could be smaller or larger irritants.   Achievements are almost nonexistent and consist only of character/place/information unlocks and chapter completeions.  More significantly, he points at which the player takes physical control of Bigby's movements can be a bit awkward; I've never been a fan of straight up WASD movement controls (no mouse involvement). Fighting mechanics are extremely simplistic, consisting of random direction dodging, mouse clicks on targetted areas and fillling up a strength bar through keymashing. As these aspects are not the larger focus of the game, I have a great deal of forgiveness for it, even though Bigby took quite a few unnecessary punches due to unclear timing while I was in the driver's seat. In my opinion, the graphic style, plot and voice acting made up more than admirably for any wonky mini fights/detection scenarios.  I can't speak to the replayability of the game at this time, but would seem to be enough alternate choices that it could well warrant 2 or more additional runs of the campaign.  A hearty thumbs up for a visually pleasing game. Great characters, excellent story, well put together. A perfect tie-in to an Eisner award winning title.

Loved this game. Enjoyed the voice acting and the story, although I felt the quick time events were at times a little too sudden (I once stretched my arms during a chapter and missed a couple of them). Overall really enjoyed it however, and recommend it for others who love a good story, especially given the craze for all things fairy tale these days (Grimm, Once upon a Time, etc.).  Criticisms. Quick-time events as noted above were often really sudden and could catch one off guard if they weren't paying close attention at a point, which is why I would recommend pausing the game whenever you aren't full attention. Also, very linear in terms of interactions, very few things that provide depth to the in-game world outside of anything directly relevant to the storyline.  Regardless, worth a buy, especially if it's on sale at a given time.

Great story in a very unusual setting. If you have enjoyed Telltale's previous adventure experiences you will most likely love this one too. The gameplay is pretty basic (well, duh), you select dialogue titles and sometimes do QTE, which seem to be impossible to fail. It is most certainly not the strong part of the game, but it will do. The strong part is the story, set in rich setting of Fabletown, the town where all the Fables (characters from stories, myths and so on) live in modern times. You play as a hard-♥♥♥ Big Bad Wolf (or sheriff Bigby Wolf, whatever you like) going through the story to unravel a series of mysterious events. The dialogues are great, characters are interesting, the ending is pretty spectacular. Actually the ending is so good, that the community still can't decide what happened :D   Anyway, if you can handle a game being not much of a game, but more like a TV series with some interaction, this surely is a mustplay.

More of an experience than a game, but that doesn't mean that you don't interact or effect how things turn out. The story plays out like a noire, a noire with fables from the the tales told ever since the most olden of times. You (the player) play as Bigby Wolf, which unsurprisingly, just so happens to be the big bad wolf. Only now, he's taken up a new life where he walks around in human form, taking on the role as sheriff, exclusively so for the rest of the fables. Of course, much like the real world, everybody is always unhappy with something, regardless if you're doing your best to please them or just letting them drown in their own misery. It essentially comes down to your own conscience of morality. Ask someone politely to leave before things get nasty or cut straight to the chase by ripping a guys arm off to show that you're not messing around, the choice is yours  The five chapters are thuroughly solid throughout and with regular accord leave you numerous opportunities that will embrace a complacent feeling within you. The music is varied and the art style is gorgeously stunning and perhaps the most appealing aspect about the entire game, truly fitting for telling the story it does. Add the price drop to the whole picture and I honestly see no reason not to do yourself a favour and download this gem that will hook it's fangs into you from beggining to bitter end.

This is one of my favorite games of all time. For those who aren't aware, it revolves around a bunch of different fairy-tale characters called Fables, such as Snow White, Ichabod Crane, The Little Mermaid, and most importantly, the Big Bad Wolf. The game is tailored by the choices you make, and your decisions can lead to good or bad things later down the road, as I'm sure most of you who have played Telltale games before already know.   The reason I loved this game so much is because it takes a bunch of fairy-tale characters that you already know and puts them all together in this dark, grimy story, and it's really interesting to see it all. That's also the reason I enjoyed this more than The Walking Dead; the setting was just overall more appealing to me, and I really liked The Walking Dead, so if you're like me, you will love this game.  Overall, the story is excellent and the only real complaint I have is one I have also had with The Walking Dead, and that is the fact that some of the dialogue choices aren't clear whether they are going to be nice or mean, and you might end up picking something thinking it's going to be one thing and really it's the other. The dialogue can also be iffy at times, but it doesn't take away from the story whatsoever, just a small annoyance. I really love this game, and I recommend it to anyone who appreciates Telltale games and dark, fairy-tale stories.

If you played either of the walking dead games (season 1 or 2) than you are most likely going to love this game. The story takes place in the bronx of New York City. You Play as sheriff Bigby Wolf AKA. The Big Bad Wolf. You are challenged with a murder investigation, and the rest goes on from there.  This game is a very well built choose your own adventure game, and when it says that every choice you make decides the game for you, Telltale REALLY meant it. For the full Experiance of this game I would recommend playing it through twice.  The entire plot of this game is separated into 5 shocking, dark, and exciting episodes.  The amount of Characters in this game is astounding. To explain It would say, think of every fairy tale and nursery ryme you have ever heard. Thats basically the characters in this game.  If you couldn't tell already, I absoulutly adore this game. Telltale is famous for hand crafting amazing stories, and this game proves that. The story is really dark, and brooding, You want to know what is going to happen next. And how all of the characters are in the state they are in, is very interesting to see.  Now I know that I have made this seem like this game can do no wrong, their are a few things wrong with this game. The first of which being, THAT THE GAME IS SOOOOO SHORT! This game took me only 6 hours two complete, for me thats about 3 sittings. If you played the walking dead than this wouldn't surpise you, and the game kind of makes up for it with its replay value, but IMO its way to short. A second problem I had is that there were some very strange gamebreaking bugs that happened ever so often. The bug wouldn't let me select a option to talk and would skip the scenes and than go back to the scenes that it skipped, just a weird bug though.  All in all, this game is fantastic, a must buy, IMO one of the greatest stories ever told in gaming. 9/10!

Of course, since the last episode of this hasn't been released, I am not yet fully entitled to write a review for this game. However, I felt it was necessary because TellTales has done it again (after The Walking Dead both season 1 and 2 which I have tried so many times to review but could never put my feelings into words about these) and created a game that is simply stunning.   - The gameplay is easy and smooth, despite some staccato in the dialogue (For example being able to change from an overly positive response to a negative one and getting the same reaction from other characters) - The storyline is captivating  - The cliffhangers have killed me more than once - The characters each have their perks and their faults which really made this game special for me  - Bigby (Need I say more?)  Overall, a great game, strongly recommend it.

That being said this is definetly worth the investment!

Definitely worth playing, if you can get along with the storytelling in Telltale games. It feels a lot like a TV series or movie, the dialogue is brilliant and you'll find yourself chuckling a bit at it probably too at times.  While the controls are not always that great, they also aren't much of a hurdle either.  The only thing I really didn't like was, when the timer ran at a kinda awkward speed and I missed two kinda (for me at least) important dialogue options by simply clicking a milisecond too late. Then you sit there and go 'hhhrmpf' and there is no way to rewind the time a bit, would be a neat feature if you ask me, because It's not always entirely obvious how fast the timer runs, until you look down from the text. So, yeah, imho if you didn't choose anything, inadvertently, you should maybe be allowed to rewind to the last dialogue promp, more could maybe destroy the replay value too much.  The characters are refreshingly non-twodimensional for the most part, which is also a big plus. Also pretty sure that these kinds of games, due to the art-style, will stay evergreens for a long time, since they got that comic-look down almost perfectly.  Definitely looking forward to the last episode and don't regret getting it.

man where to do i even began, i guess lets start with this. THE ART STYLE. now i love cell shading, like i love it, i adore it, i want more of it. its one of the reasons i love borderlands so much.  but this game takes the cell shading beauty to nice new place, a place of grit, a place you might find a PI  its great, what else can i say, my laptop is pretty darn good but ive played this on other lesser laptops, if you have the gear to run this game it looks great.  i had tiny bit of stuttering during the whole last time on the wolf amoung us bits, but every telltale game does that.   now for the story.. i loved it. its gritty, its bold and its got more twists and turns then 'lombard street'. it lives up to the fables comics nicely. 'google it if you dont get it'  its nice mature tale and it can get pretty heavy really fast. the thing about it is, the cast may seem very flip floppy, but thast more on you then them. figure out what type of bigby you are and stay to it. dont flop from over the top pleasing to over the top attack everyone. pick a role. makes the tale smoother and better, gives it much more depth  now for the action or other click based stuff. its telltale game guys and gals, it moves like you think it does. solidly movement if a bit rigid when walking but all in all its pleasant, the quick time events flow smoothly for me though some may find the them to be faster then alot of games do it.  the fights are dramatic in the way that an old Pi film is, a bit over the top, maybe a bit to zealous in thier performance, but frankly its what the game needs. pleasantly plopping you from dialogue to crime solving into an extreme fight at pace i find very well done.  and the game keeps you on your toes, some events are out of the blue or others you can feel coming. some are unavoidable and just ♥♥♥♥ing happen.  needless to say id give this game ten out of ten, great art, fluid movemnets, a nice mature grit filled tale depth if you stay your role and dont flip more then two faces coin. and the soundtrack, aww its perfect..   to sum it up, the wolf amoung not only nails a killer title, it nails everything the game needs to to impress and draw you back.  and when ♥♥♥♥ hits the fan. THE BIG BAD WOLF is on your side. lucky you.  welcome to fabletown   A GAMEINSOMNIA REVIEW  Potato Dono out,PEACE!

The wolf among us has to have one of the best stories in a game that i've ever encountered. You find yourself taking on the role of sherif Bigby trying to solve a murder mystery; however with the amounts of twist and deviations in the story you are always having to second guess yourself even up until the point when you find out who'd done it. I certainly recommend this game not so much as a game but as a new form of interactive digital media and story telling. If you're a film or tv series fan then this game is definitely for you.

A new exciting game from Telltale Games, the company behind The Walking Dead videogame. This one is based on the comic books of Fables by Bill Willingham, but you don't need to read those to know what universe you are rolling into. The art is beautiful, even more comicbook-like than the Walking Dead with beautiful use of colour. You play as Bigby, the sheriff of the fairytale figures who ended up in New York a long time ago. The episodes have a noir-feel to it and I like that.   As you play with Bigby you decide how he should behave. Is he using violence or does he talk everyone into admitting the trouble they are in? Almost good cop, bad cop you might say. But I won't spoil more about the story itself. Only downside are the controls for the PC in quick time events, they feel a bit clumsy. When you are caught up in the game you have to look down to find them (at least I did). I'd say that if you liked The Walking Dead and you like a somewhat dark story about fairytale characters trying to get along with eachother and theirselves without losing their heads: Definetely try this out!

Telltale just never fails to impress. 'The Wolf Among Us' is a unique twist on fairy tale characters; putting them in the real, modern world and having them all involved in a mysterious murder.   You play as the Big Bad Wolf himself, Bigby Wolf (real name, pun intended), who is the detective of a hidden community of fairy tale characters in New York City. Fairy tale characters are immortal, and can't die unless certain 'conditions' are met (no spoilers). But when one of the fable's heads is left on Bigby's doorstep, it's up to him to solve the mystery of the murder and bring justice to the townsfolk.  For fans of visual novels (or 'choose-your-own-story' games if you prefer that), mysteries and (occasional) quick-time events, this is definitely the game for you!

I end up getting drawn to games from odd places, in 'The Wolf Among Us'' case, the odd place was Miracle of Sound's 'Dog's Life' tribute song. The song is great of course, but the visual style and colour (my goodness, the colour!) I saw in the music video made it a must get. Now I've played it I'm really glad I picked it up. It's also convinced me to give the comics a go, something I wouldn't have considered had I not had an introduction to the world and characters first. (Frankly the premise alone sounded a little odd, and the recent appearance of 'Once' on telly (with it's similar hook) just seemed really corny in a Buffy and Charmed meets disney properties way). But, this game! This is the first proper modern style point and click I have played and finished (30 mins of Life is Strange doesn't really count) and the only TellTale game I've played to my knowledge. So, if you're not a fan of that style of game play, i.e. wandering around looking at things and doing QTEs this might not be for you. On the other hand, the murder-mystery plot actually lends itself to this style of game as you methodically search crime scenes and navigate dialogue options to make a prisoner open up or talk you way out of a sticky situation.  But eventually punches are going to get thrown, you are afterall, stepping into the shoes of Fabletown's chain smoking detective Bigby Wolf; reformed Big, Bad Wolf now werewolf trying to balance justice with staying alive. The Telltale engine doesn't feel totally geared towards full scale action but it's nicely presented with good cuts between moments and relatively few of those sticky jumps you get from option based gameplay. As I mentioned the semi-cell shaded comic book style visuals really suits the game. Besides being consistantly nice to look at there's a great 80's style vibe with lots of neon pops of colour as well richly detailed interiors, the most impressive being the Woodlands Business Office and several of the appartments which all reflect their owner's personalities. Having never met the characters of Fabletown before I was pleasently suprised by the characters who appeare and how they are portrayed. As an example, in episode 1 you'll meet a down on his luck landlord Toad of Toadhall complete with british accent and Collin, one of the three little pigs, who crashes at Bigby's place because Bigby owns him one for that one time when his house was blown down... The sound design is also rather good. The voice cast is well chosen and the vocals never feel jarringly out of tone. The music is very fitting with the main theme being a particular favourite of mine. Some of the sound effects are also rather marvalous, an ememy from Episode 5 has particularly chilling sound design. Besides that, Bigby's wolfish nature often bubbles up as growls and snarls which work rather well.  If there's one ctiticism I have it's this: I've played through the game twice with a couple of different choices made but I've yet to discover just how drastically different characters will act depending on what you say or how you act. Indeed an early choice drastically changes the outcome of a stituation with only the barest clue as to what the outcome would be if you chose the alternative path. I've yet to do a 'big, bad wolf' run as it were where I pick the most agreesive, violent and nasty options and I think I will find it hard simply because I've come to like the characters too much. Final word of warning, if you don't notice the age rating prior to playing like I did (I'm at an age where I don't need to bother about them, y'see) you might be suprised by the adult language and themes (it's based on fairy tales after all!). Just be warned. I'm usually a bit sensitive to that sort of thing (especially violence and gore) but the game being styalised how it is goes a long way. If you'd rather not hear anthropomorphic toads swear like cockney gangsters this game might not be for you. If you can get past that, you're in for a treat.  'The Wolf Among Us' gets a very firm recomendation from me.   Tl:dr Great film noir murder mystery story Gorgeous visuals Fun characters Replay value
One of telltale's better games. Really atmospheric, unique game with one of the most interesting backstories out there.

Like with their adaption of The Walking Dead, Telltale once again creates an immensely captivating and enthralling visual novel/point and click hybrid with light (yet satisfying) QTE segments and of course, choices. In TWAU, your choices matter.   Sure, in the grand scheme of things the endings are all along the same lines, but your actions, their effects on the world, characters and your own sense of justice all make a difference throughout the game. What makes this interesting is that you'll constantly be piecing together mysteries, meaning decisions can fall under both moral and logical umbrellas.   If you've played any of the Ace Attorney games (or similar) and found the linear 'safety harness' preventing you from falling too far from the correct train of thoughts irritating, you'll be pleased to know TWAU is not afraid to let you go off the tracks a bit. For example, I'm considering replaying the game myself simply because I felt I made some poor decisions regarding what to investigate, who to accuse, and so on.  The game is VERY linear, although of course scenes can and will play out differently depending on your actions (and you get some opportunities to visit different areas over others in search of clues). As the game's protagonist, Bigby Wolf, 'you' have a reasonable degree of ways to interpret his character, from a team player to a lone wolf (ha) and anywhere inbetween.  My only really complaint with the game that sometimes I felt there were scenes where none of the dialogue options really fitted what I wanted to say, but those times were infrequent and didn't have much of an impact on my enjoyment or immersion.  So basically, TWAU is a fantastic murder mystery tale with well-written characters, a satisfying story which never slows down and which pulls some impressive twists. If you even have a vague interest in what you've see and read, I wouldn't hesitate to recommend it.

The Wolf Among Us is a game that no one should miss. It is funny how something like this, an episodic series that relies heavily on dialogue choices can be more compelling and fun than a full retail release like Beyond Two Souls. Tell-tale has the unique ability to make a story that draws the player in, then use brutal sequences to question the players own morales and actions.  Having played The Walking Dead, there would be a massive connection to the characters. But the twist they through at the end of episode 1... Needless to say, I was not ready for what happens, nor would anybody else.   The only problem that I have is the long wait between episodes, probably because of the amount of projects that tell-tale has taken on, such as Tales from the Borderlands, and a Game of Thrones game, both apparently going to be episodic series as well. Even though I look forward to them, I really wish they would hurry up The Wolf Among Us  A final note: If you want to experience a piece of crap game that poses as art, buy a David Cage game like Beyond Two Souls (and believe me the hate for it is not unwarrented)  If you want a game that can truly be considered art, that goes beyond story to bring a fufilling experince to almost every one who plays it, and is definetly worth more than its relatively cheap price, buy a game from Tell-Tale  Buy The Wolf Among Us

The Wolf Among us is the Walking Dead games done right. The Wolf Among us is an enclosed, single-season experience, and so it is given the ability to make its choices truly matter. There is enough similarity that there could be a sequel (and I, for one, certainly wouldn't mind it,) but even so. The story is fantastically well-written, and the characters feel lifelike enough for you to get a real feel of how they will act under certain circumstances (which is necessary to make some of the tougher decisions). If I HAD to have a complaint with the game, it'd be that you can't get every achievement on a single playthrough, and some achievements require that you make rather deplorable decisions. But they're just achievements, who cares?  I can't recommend The Wolf Among Us enough. It is a perfect Noire-themed murder mystery with an ending that leaves you thirsty for more, yet nonetheless thoroughly satisfied.  Score: 9.75/10 Letter Grade: A Dollars per hour off-sale : $24.99/8 hours = $3.12 / hour Dollars per hour on-sale: $6.25/8 hours = $0.78/hour  Verdict: As addicting and exquisite as a good pepperoni pizza. Telltale's The Wolf Among Us - Episode One: Faith Review by Paul V.  Like many of you; I pre-order this game, looking forword to what Telltale had planned for bring this Vertigo Comic to life!! I was a little disappointed when; like many of us, had to wait for hours past the release time for the game to be made available! Finally the time had come; and I was downloading and installing the game as fast as my system would process.  I played a little over 2 hours; and the game was over! That's right! Two Hours Long! Shortest game I ever played! As disappointing has this may sound; I couldn't stop playing the game. I loved every minute of it; and in the end, wanted more!! But this is a episodic game; and so my $25 when for all five episodes, for which I now have to wait until Telltale releases the second part; Smoke & Mirrors. It's like reading the freakin comic book!! You get it. Read the hell out of it, and now have to wait til next month for #2!!  Aaaaaarrrrrrhhhhh!!!!  But I'm hooked!! I want more!! I want to play again; but I'm afraid my new choices will change the game play when E2 comes out. So I'll wait until all five are out and done with before playing it again; so as not to change any of the relationships I have set in motion! All go for the acheivements then, too.  If you are thinking of picking it up; go for it!! If you feel like waiting for all five parts to be out; I say, if you can wait that long, go for it!! Either way; this game was worth the wait and the two hour play time!!﻿  P.S. Game Informer magazine stated the The Wolf Among Us; 'Made the Wolf Inside Us Hungry For More', and I totally agree!!

Telltale's crowning achievement to date, The Wolf Among Us stands as a high water mark for this brand of storytelling. It is filled with compelling characters and a dense noir story ripe for fevered dissection between episodes. The ending left me breathless and staggered, craving with everything inside of me that we do, indeed, get a Season 2. Yes, there are the Fables comic books, which are lovely, but there is something about controlling the action yourself that just draws you into a narrative.  This game is not for those looking for involving or challenging gameplay. Fight sequences are a means to an end, roadblocks between you and the story conclusion you so richly desire.  Heartwrenching and enthralling, The Wolf Among Us is worth whatever the current asking price.

There were quite a few times I wasn't sure I wanted to make the choice I made and went back to fix it; even if it was really gratifying at the time to do something that may make your life more difficult later. If you're looking for something that plays like a movie and sucks you in fast, this is your game. The only real downside I had was that there were two occasions where it bugged out after Episode 3 (the on screen choices wouldn't do anything and where labeled strangely) but exiting and restarting the game fixed it quickly. Long story short, definitely glad I bought this and would reccommend it to anyone.

Seems barely relevant now, since thousands of reviews have been written here, leading to a deserved Overwhelmingly Positive status for this game, but I'll hop on that bandwagon. It's the perfect game for players who just want to immerse into a cool fairytale world, more like an interactive movie than actual game-playing really. You can't get stuck unless you're a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ in the quick-action 'fight' scenes, the main challenge is to get all the Achievements from trying out various dialogue branches over at least a couple of playthroughs and seeing where different choice paths lead.  I wasn't aware of the Fables comics before playing this, just like I wasn't aware that The Walking Dead was based on comics (not the TV show), and the Bone games, and even the Puzzle Agent games. Telltale does a good job of popularizing these brilliantly creative worlds with those of us who don't really buy comics.  It is quite a violent game, but only in that detached comical way, and of course adult themes prevail throughout, so if that's all cool with you and you're just up for some casual gameplay, go out and buy this. But its full price is a little bit high I'd say, definitely wishlist it and wait until it comes down to at least -50%. I say that here, but I almost always do this in my game purchases anyway. The only games I've ever paid full (pre-order) prices for were Grim Fandango: Remastered and Dreamfall Chapters.

Telltale Studios came into the spotlight with their Walking Dead game — which went on to win many, many game of the year awards and the praise of consumers and critics alike. It was also a game that I didn't particularly care for. Admittedly, I only played the first two chapters and the voice acting and gameplay was quite good, but the story itself did not grab me like it seemed to do to others. I'm over the whole zombie thing. However, with The Wolf Among Us, Telltale has successfully recaptured my attention. They've produced a high-quality game with careful attention to good storytelling. While the gameplay might be minimal, the performances, direction, and script will keep you invested till the last moment.  If I were to describe The Wolf Among Us, I'd say it's equal parts Drive, and Chinatown with the aesthetic of something like Only God Forgives. It's a intricate detective story (an immediate interest for me) following the Big Bad Wolf (now just called Bigby, in his human form) as he teams up with Snow White in the search for a serial killer who's recent actions have disturbed the 'peaceful' community of Fabletown — a community of fairy tale characters located in the Bronx New York. However, as Bigby progresses, he tests the limits of himself (physically and mentally), his friends, and the community as he unravels a plot much bigger than himself. The plot starts off great and just keeps getting better. There's a constant sense of mystery, a legitimate interest in the results of the case, and the identity of the perpetrator. Telltale's script is tight and focused, yet allowing for ample amounts of flexibility and player choice. The dialogue is perfectly delivered by the accomplished voice actors, adding to the gritty mix of realism and fantasy. The story is just plain great — it checks off all the important boxes for success and even adds a few more. While the ending may feel a little messy in its ultimately satisfying payoff, the plot is riveting from start to finish. It clocks in at a solid length too, it can probably be finished in anywhere from 8-12 hours, depending on how much stuff you investigate. The replayability comes almost entirely from the choice based gameplay — allowing players to play again, choosing different dialogue paths. In addition, there are a few hidden 'Book of Fables' pages that can be unlocked from different choices and investigations. It's an engaging ride, and one that keeps you thinking and wanting for more.  Like I said, the gameplay is pretty minimal. When boiled down, it's comprised of quicktime combat events and investigation scenes in a mix of classic point-and-click gameplay and L.A. Noire investigation. I would've been perfectly happy with The Wolf Among Us being a TV miniseries, but it works very well as a game. The choice aspects and quick-time combat involve the player enough to be a true gaming experience. The combat is pretty fun, and adds to the game viscerally, but there are the occasional 'mash Q' button prompts that are impossible to win (according to the story). It's a tad frustrating, but not a big gripe. Overall, the gameplay is mostly comprised of ticking dialogue boxes, but the aforementioned high production values keep the game interesting.   The graphics are simply gorgeous. The game's aesthetic is alluringly saturated, giving off a distinct 80s/neo-noir vibe. The comic book mixed with realism is a style Telltale is known for, and it works just as well as it did in The Walking Dead. It's also clear that Telltale's trademark aesthetic is not a cheap way of using lower quality assets, but a deliberate artistic choice that wouldn't have worked in any other way. The Wolf Among Us is slick, gorgeous, and tremendously rendered.   It's also nice to know that Wolf doesn't use its fairy tale setting as a gimmick. This story could have only been told with these characters. It could've ended up as a lame detective story with normal characters reskinned as fables. However, the tales and the characters involved ingrained in the story's core so as to where they're integral. Good on Telltale for that one.   All in all, I'd be surprised if The Wolf Among Us is not among the ranks of my 'best of 2014' list when that day comes. A twisted, dark fairly tale mystery with immaculate visuals and superb voice acting, writing, and direction. Here's hoping we get a season 2.  4/5

Not as epic or involving as their seminal and as yet unrivalled The Walking Dead game, but an enjoyable romp in a unique 'fantasy in reality' setting based on an indie comic book series. Each chapter is only 90 mins long maximum apparently. It actually works for this game, but not for others.

Wolf Among Us by now is well known on many platforms. It is one of Telltale games best. Pros A: Rich, hysterical and fun kick ♥♥♥ type adventure.  B: Great humor and wonderful choice driven gameplay C: Big plus is all the episodes are done so your not waiting months for a new one. D: If you love fairy tales and DC's classic Comic type stories this one is for you. E: Great voice acting, wonderful surprises and a beautiful drawn animation. F; Sequel is coming one day so nice addition to have. PSP PC controller friendly Cons A: I am not sure if your choices matter or not. B: Very engaging despite the fact your not really risking bad moves in the game. C: Follow the game rating, some subject matter not suitable for children.  D: Could be a con like most films once you see it once, you may need time to go over it again.  OVERALL: Like all telltale adventures pretty straight forward storytelling with manuevers that can repeated if failed, so no real way to do so. Take alook at gameplay in Workshop. If Adventures are your thing. This is a must have and one of Telltales best. I would wait till it is on sale at 50/75% off and absolute steal and great game to add to your library: My Score 4 out of 5 stars.

This is quality product but I felt deceived enough to write a review after finishing it.   This is not a 'game' in any sense. It is a comic/graphic novel brought to life. Decisions made in the game don't do much beyond adding different flavor text as the story progresses. The course of the narrative cannot change in any meaningful way.  There is added action and combat situations. These involve hitting WASD keys as they light up, overlapping a cursor circle over other circles on the screen, and tapping 'Q'. These are easy enough that they become more tedious than engaging.   If you want an interactive story this game is for you. If you want to watch a desperate Little Mermaid make her living as a stripper this game is for you. Just be well aware going in that this is not a puzzle, adventure, action, choose your own adventure game, or anything of that ilk in the slightest.   Synopsis: this is the only game I've fallen asleep playing but still bothered to finish.

Pros:  -Memorable, engaging plotline -Multiple options for playstyle -Perfect visual style -Perfect music -Easy, intuitive gameplay -Rewind feature -Extras give more detail about game world -Amazing ending   Cons:  -Relatively short -Many choices do not matter -No fast forward option for replaying longer scenes   Overall:  The Wolf Among Us is a storytelling game. You pick the main character's dialogue choices and, occasionally, participate in quick time events. But the entire game is very scripted. So while you do get a great deal of roleplaying, the actual 'gameplay' is very shallow. That's not to say it isn't fun.  In fact, this is the first game that I have played just for relaxation in a long time. Most of the time I like being challenged, or I like achievement hunting, or beating that secret boss, or so on. This game rewards you just for playing, and the achievements work similarly. I got 100% achievements here not because it was a challenge, but because doing so meant experiencing more of the world, and I wanted to do that anyway. In a way, the achievements let the player know 'there's more here that you missed', and that was compelling.  It's like an interactive movie. It's worth playing, and you can get at least two solid playthroughs out of this, if not more. There are so many options that have so many different ramifications down the line that I still could go back and explore some more. Buy the game, you won't regret it.   Bottom Line:  Absolutely worth it.

The Wolf Among Us delivers a fantastic, well conceived story with compelling characters, meaningful consequences for the player's choices, and beautiful art direction. The narrative moves forward exploring mature themes surrounding a murder while leveraging the conceit that the main characters from legendary fables inhabit our present day world. For anyone seeking a good gaming experience centered on a well consructed mystery, The Wolf Among Us is a terrific place to spend your time.

For me, this is the hidden gem of Telltale's lineup. Not as many people have discovered it perhaps because it's based on a lesser-known property (the acclaimed and much-loved long-running comic series 'Fables') than some of Telltale's bigger releases like 'The Walking Dead' and 'Game of Thrones'. But of course, relationship to source material often isn't a major factor in what makes a game great. And I think Telltale's bespoke engine and particular graphical style are more suited to this release than any other I've seen to date. The comic book stylings, stark contrasts and (in this case, neon) tones really shine and seem to 'make sense' more in this game than any of their others.  It plays just like the other interactive Telltale adventures and the quality of writing and emotional impact is every bit as strong as what I've come to expect from them.  If you've enjoyed any other Telltale-style game and/or are up for a dark and gritty, constantly-engaging, urban fantasy tale, you should definitely pick this one up!! It functions as a wholly satisfying self-contained story, but I'm hoping they pick up this series for a well-deserved 2nd season.

So... 'The Wolf Among Us', a Telltale Game based on the acclaimed comic book series 'Fables'. I never heard of the comics before the game. So I went into this game without any prior knowledge about the lore. I loved its noir style, the story, and the main character as well as a few of the secondary/supporting roles carry the story really well. The game does a very good job in hooking you into the story and introducing to you in this world. This fantasy world right underneath our (human) noses.   It has an engaging storytelling, and the choices you make might not carry much complexity and endings as recent Telltale Games (i.e. TWD Season 2, Batman Telltale), BUT... it's not a game I don't mind revisiting regardless. So if you are looking to get lost in a mystery/detective story set in a world too small for fable characters not to collide... this is the game for you!  My only sorrow is that there wasn't a Season 2 for this game... Telltale Games, I love you but you broke my heart by not making a Season 2. Unless, there is one coming...

As you make your way through the dialogue options The Wolf Among us, the game periodically give you little notes about how your choices affect the story and the other characters. A little alert might pop up to tell you something like:  <!>  You told the truth   <!>  You connected the evidence   <!>  Snow will remember that you took her side   Of course, a more honest alert might sound more like this:  <i>  Your decision has been carefully recorded for posterity and immediately flushed down the toilet   Nothing you decide in this game matters, which wouldn't be a huge deal except for the fact that decision making is the  sole game mechanic . It's tough to give players real choices because it requires a lot more content for the same amount of play time. Other games have run into this issue and some have found innovative solutions.  The Stanley Parable leaned right into it, making the very concept of player agency part of the story. Gone Home, a game in which literally everything that happened happened before the the protagonist even entered the narrative, built uncertainty and used environmental storytelling keep the player engaged. Wolf unfortunately has no tricks up its sleeve to balance its series of pointless 'choices.'  Maybe the biggest problem isn't that the choices aren't meaningful, it's that the game won't let you forget how meaningless they are for even one second. Between chapters it asks the player to sit through a recap of the previous chapter and a preview of the next, both of which serve as reminders of how linear and immutable the plot is. It's as if the game wants to constantly remind you about all of the events that are going to happen no matter what you do.  It doesn't help that the plot sometimes feels like an arbitrary string of red herrings and unconvincing fake-outs. We may see a character shot in the chest in one scene, only to to be told in the next that they're fine because of magic or whatever. In a fictional universe where the rules of magic are never totally spelled out, these kinds of  deus ex machina  moments are inevitable and they don't need to ruin the story, but too many of them in a row can make the stakes just seem very, very low.  It's kind of a bummer because there are some great things about the game. The voice acting is perfect and the writing faithfully recreates the weird, gritty fairytale world of the comics. The art is also pretty much dead-on in matching the comics while adding some dynamic elements, although some of the character movements push it into the uncanny valley. You can also expect to spend a few minutes on google trying to figure out how to fix the game's totally hideous lack of anti-aliasing (luckily it is fixable).   I marked this review, 'not recommended', but my thoughts on it are more mixed than that. I do intend to finish the game, I'm just disappointed.

So after dumping my whole weekend into this game I make the final choice, then I experience the apparently notorious 'This choice is blank' glitch that effectively corrupts the save file. THEN when I tried to reload the save file instead of bringing me to my last checkpoint it threw me in the middle of chapter 1, and it autosaved. great. since loading the latest checkpoint was no longer an option I opted to just start over from the trial at the well but guess what? attempting to do that doesn't work either, it just starts over from the beginning of the chapter with NONE of the choices I had made up to that point. completely ruined the game for me. Thanks alot telltale, guess they were too busy counting their money to bother fixing game breaking glitches like this one. I won't forget this and I won't spend another dollar on a game with the telltale name on it. Play this game at your own risk. You've been warned.

I dont know what it is, I have a 2015 macbook pro and the graphic settings are lower then what I have for Tales from the borderlands but it still is not working. everything is up to date and I have more then enough gigs of space for the game to run smoothly. Feel free to skip this game. Whether you're considering buying it, or investing time in playing, in my opinion it's not worth it (and I got it at -75%).  Having played and greatly appreciated 'The Walking Dead' 1 and 2, my experience with 'The Wolf Among Us' was disappointingly underwhelming.   The story.  My biggest complaint obviously, since this is an adventure game. Basically it's a murder story with unknown motive or means. It's not gripping, nor immersive. There's hardly any character development, no relationships development. The intrigue is really dull, gives little explanation and excitment. Introduces new meaningless characters all the time, and doesn't even wrap up properly, with any kind of finale or uncovering of the grand scheme. You stumble upon some facts and scraps of actions which in my opinion only serve the purpose to have another dumb quicktime-event section.  Your choices NEVER introduce any meaningful consequences, all the while you're being fed these info popups in the corner of the screen like 'Snow will remember that'. Yea, may bloody be, but the only implication of this will be a subtle 2-seconds-long smile she'll exchange with you some time later. Not only that, but these popups keep appearing  till the last 30 seconds of the game  leaving nothing but bitter disappointment when you hit the ending OF A BINARY CHOICE; yea you read that right, this game has an open, unexplained ending, followed by a screen sending you to a website with comics for sale, set in the Fables' universe, and guess what -- THERE'S NO SECOND SEASON. (I mean,  it's not like it would make anything better  ACTUALLY I'D HATE THESE PEOPLE.) I felt pain in the groin that moment.   I don't know guys, I'm so disappointed I don't know how to put it into words. Read other negative rewievs - the accusations of being a quick-time-event-driven (un)interactive film echo over and over.  The music layer I haven't even paid a single thought throughout the game - it's so irrelevant. The graphics are super stylish, but sadly don't really matter...  Also game crashed twice.

Summary: The mediocre writing sometimes slides into pure disappointment. Fabletown could have been done better.  My wife and I played The Wolf Among Us together. We didn't completely hate it, but we were extremely disappointed by the poor writing and the deviations in character behavior of characters from the graphic novels. Snow White in particular was poorly done, and she is one of the main characters of this story. On the other hand, we did enjoy what time was spent with Bufkin as he is one of my wife's favorite characters and was done reasonably well.  We have played other Telltale games and it is almost always the same - just enough goodness to keep you playing, but riddled with plotholes, inconsistencies in character behavior, a lack of options where it counts (did anyone else want to call a doctor for the man whose guts were sticking out rather choosing between murdering him or leaving him to die?), and in general just poor writing. The first episode was great, the second less so, the third involved a couple of moments where we looked at each other wondering what just happened, and by the end we were having a tough time caring about the characters or how it ended. The writing slid downhill _that_ bad.   My wife and I have also played both seasons of The Walking Dead along with Jurassic Park and a couple other Telltale games. We knew what we were getting into, we had hoped that with all the positive reviews it would be better. The first episode started out with such promise, we were hooked - but in the end, we will not be recommending this game to anyone, not even my wife's best friend who adores the Fables graphic novels.  If you love Fables, and are OK with drama rather than good writing, then you'll probably enjoy this game. Otherwise I recommend looking elsewhere, and probably not at another Telltale game.

This is an example of to much of the same thing. Telltale keeps putting the same game out but reskins it. Game of thrones, Wolf amoung us, Walking dead 1&2, Borderlands. All having the same controls and same concept. They also claim that you have a huge effect on the story but thats that really true. Usually your just picking between sides between factions, and alot of railroading.  Ill talk a bit more about the wolf among us. The strong start out strong but quickly gets to deluded. A women you save from your arch nemesis head shows up on your doorstep. this sets up out mystery, but the game steers away from this and turns into standerd telltale. The mystery begins to feel like an after thought. All evidance collected in a chapter is deleted when starting the next one. Then at the end of the game they just tell you who did it. Which makes this game feel more like an action trhiller than atmospheric mystery game.  You have minimal effect on the story, and only two scenarios where you effect the outcome. Scenario One is mostly choosing your side or snow white's side, or the side of the other person who is currently in the scene. Scenario two Is based on if you kill the bad guy or just arrest him.

Mixed bag starts great, 3rd chapter is when it gets dull, and choices start becoming less and less to what I really meant or expected to say. 4th chapter is short and really uninteresting, reused situations and reliance on QTE action to keep things interesting when it's really just dragging out a story I cared about until nothing happened for two whole chapters.  basically, if the finale is great, I would recommend, but as it stands, no, it's just missing something vital.
Good Graphics Interesting Story No real challenge mentally, but the 70s called and want their 'WASD' keys back when it comes to fighting.

While the game is fairly interesting, and the story is definitely great, it has a lot of failings too. First (and most severe IMO) is the incredibly obnoxious 'Next Time On'/'Previously On' recap, that while it might be useful for some players, for those of us that are just trying to play the game without monthlong breaks, it's just an annoying waste of time.   Second are the quicktime events, which generally don't give you nearly enough time to react, especially on a touchpad. Likewise, dialog choices make the choice for you far too quickly, giving you no time to think unless you want to pause the game. Finally, being unable to skip dialog, in a game that is essentially a giant cutscene, gets old fast.   Also...no way to edit keybinds? Seriously? It's 2015.

Poorly set up, choices are too fast to really decide anything. Then they do not really alter the story line much when they are used. Fight scenes hide your cursor and leave you with litttle time to react to the fight when you do finally see it.  Worse many times the letters do nothing when pushed so you just die over and over without recourse.

Saves often fail to carry across which prompts me to restart chapters until the save will at last work. This has happened on multiple occasions and as of the most recent one, i have to go back from episode 4 to episode 1. I have heard that failed game save transfers is a common thing among telltale games (eg. The Walking Dead). For an episodic game, it would be beyond sensible to ensure that the decisions made in previous chapters carry across otherwise i see very little point in the entire game revolving around those decisions and the consequences they bring in following chapters.   The game is far more exciting, from my point of view, than The Walking Dead. It has a unique story and the entire 'detective' type of game play i got to take part in was simply fun. Albeit i would have liked more content, as hard as that is to say (I won't go into detail, for i cannot. I blatantly feel like something was missing, perhaps it was the character, maybe i just want to delve deeper into them).   I do enjoy the game, i really do, but if a game based on decisions forgets those decisions as you progress - i'm going to struggle to approve of the game in itself. Sure, the glitch or whatever it may be does not occur all the time, but the problem en lies in the fact that it /does/ occur.  Based solely on the emptiness i felt and the absolutely atrocious, though rare 'glitch', i do not recommend spending your money on this game 'less there is a sale on which significantly reduces the price.   Without glitch: 8/10  With glitch: 6.5/10

The best story, characters and setting I have ever seen in a videogame in a type of game I absolutly hate. This should have been a movie, instead its a click to advance the story kind of game. The voice acting is amazing, the mystery will keep you guessing for hours on end, and the ending (for the most part) dosen't suck. But oh my god the gameplay. Its one big quick time event. Everything you interact with is on a timer. The dialog options, the combat, even in the middle of an investigation, an event where you want to take your time and see whats going on a    character will shoot himself if you take too long.    But at the same time I can safely say I have never been as invested in a videogame story like this one. I can 100% recommend it, but not the gameplay its represented in.

>>>>>>Final edit<<<<<  I finally got around to finishing the game! It was good. The plot was a little simple for me (I was hoping for a lot more depth in the final 2 episodes) but I still found it enjoyable. However, this game pales in comparison to Telltale's The Walking Dead season 1 or 2 which unfortunately set the benchmark very high.  TLDR whole review:  Beautiful and atmospheric, with excellent character depth and voice acting which would have benefited from a far longer and more complex story arc.  Only really has replay value if you watch another player, which can be entertaining if they choose different game variables.  Negative overall because it was simply not worth the release price, with delays to episode releases and, quite simply, insufficient instalment / overall length.  Great if you can get it for under £15, otherwise you may feel rather out of pocket.  >>>>>Edit after release of Episode 3<<<<<  As I really want to enjoy this game for a good solid few hours of immersion, I'll wait until Episode 4 is out and do a combined review of episodes 3 and 4 together. My fingers are well and truly crossed for greater episode longevity.  >>>>>Edit after Episode 2<<<<<  Still beautiful, still deep and engaging, but PITIFULLY short and woeful value for money. Just look at people's game times. Episode 2 is even shorter than Episode 1 - I meandered through in only an hour and a half.  I really was expecting more considering the amount of time it took Telltale to release this installment.  >>>>>Original Review<<<<<  This game is beautifully crafted; I thoroughly enjoyed the first episode and it will I'm sure be a pleasure to play through the remaining episodes.  However. I bought this game when it came out for at least £20 (I can't remember the initial price) and so far have only been given about 3 hours of content. I am hoping the future episodes will be longer, but frankly if the future episodes are also this length then I will feel pretty let down. 15 hours total for £20 is fairly OK for a normal game, I guess - not great, but not terrible - especially if the game is as fantastic as this one clearly is. But with a game that is also a staggered series like this one, I would actually be hoping for more content for my money, not less.  So I give it 9/10 for the game itself, because the concept and execution are both superb. But in terms of value for money (as it currently stands) it's a big let-down at 5 x 3 hours. My advice would be to wait until all 5 episodes are out and buy it and play through then, as your appetite will be better sated. This is how I tackled The Walking Dead's first five episodes and it felt absolutely fantastic (although I also felt that the chapters were longer in Walking Dead, which probably helped).  The best analogy I can think of is: at an exquisite restaurant, would you rather have 5 delicious starters spread out over a year, or one slap-up perfect 3 course meal in a year's time? For me the answer is definitely the latter, and I actually regret having the cut-off and the waiting for the next installments; but for some who can better handle the anticipation and aren't binge pleasure gluttons, you may find otherwise.

The first thing you need to remember about Wolf Among Us is that it's not a game. It's a visual novels with some action scenes.  Second thing that you need to remember is that Wolf Among Us lies to your face from the first second. At the start it tells you that the game is defined by player choices and advances based on them. As I already mentioned, this is not a game AND none of the choices offered have any lasting meaning. Don't get me wrong, the choices are made aplenty and they stay indeed - you even get to maul and murder a few characters if you like. But none of the choices mean anything to the greater story. Most of the choices don't even affect the outcome of the scene. Behind the facade of variety lies a rather linear game. Last thing you need to remember is that Wolf Among Us is incredibly short. An episode lasts around 45 minutes at best. So the whole season is around 4-4.5 hours of gameplay.  If you aren't bothered by these issues, Wolf Among Us offers a vivid setting of fables coping with modern world, decent story, familiar Telltale style and nice voice-acting. It's a quality product, but as any fable it charms the viewer with lies and deceit - smoke and mirrors as the second episode states - which leads to highly inflated scores and reviews.

Telltale have a strong pedigree with adventure games, and with overall production values. A lot of the latter is up there on the screen. Regardless, I can't reccomend this one. It's both too short, and too non-interractive. It lacks the puzzles and involving plot of Back to the Future, and the reactivity and investment of the Walking Dead, plus is shorter than either. This is Telltale's weakest work to date, and with a large number of further games in the pipeline, I'm worried that one of my favouriate studioes have substituted quantity for quality.

Gameplay 4/10 Graphics 7/10 Story 7/10  I am guessing this game is one of Telltale Games' earlier works. The reason why I suggest this is because the player controls and gameplay are very low key. By that I mean if you bought the game and all 5 of it's episodes you are forced to deal with their reviews of the chapter before and a spoiler after you finish it without being able to skip it. Now the story was pretty good at least with the path that I took and I am not spoiling it but I will say that it feels short no matter which road you take. I got it on sale so I got it for a decent match to it's value but short game, short story and not so good gameplay all work together to me giving this review. It's not like it was garbage if you average my score out you still get a 6/10 which is pretty good.  I will say that even though it's a GRAPHIC NOVEL I still expect a bit MORE gameplay as it is a game. Things that would've been enjoyable would be: 1: Getting to play the detective role more. You do it once or twice but from there in you are mostly deducing, watching the story and responding to it, or fighting with awkward mechanics. [Which would be better after/during an investigation where you actually put things together. This does occur once during the game BUT ONLY ONCE.] 2. Being able to change your choices based off the input of your allies. This game tries to put you into the moment by forcing you to think fast but really it just takes the humanity out of it. You should not only be able to choose a response but also be able to to choose to change your mind at least partially IF there is time for it. 3. Being accused for things in the game that you didn't actually do. This will happen, it's annoying. 4. 'I can't go into details right now.' This excuse for not telling somebody what is going on shouldn't be used so many times in one story and should be used as a spice. 5. Repetitive choices in the same 1 minute of choice making. This isn't fun for a player or a person. 'Wanna break his jaw? Wanna break his boombox, Wanna break his Jukebox? Wanna break his cups? Wanna break his TV?' This isn't really a spoiler because it has no influence on the story AND YET IT HAPPENS WHY? 6. It's a dark story I get it, but I think in some places where blood was excessive there were other places were there wasn't enough. Drug placement was annoying too but I guess fables don't need to worry about CANCER or being alcoholic.  7.Brutal fighting, like a lot of it and in situations where all you want is to stop the person from punching your character it seems overkill.  Aside from these bits the story was good, and the art made the story tolerable even some of the more gorey parts. It is very easy to connect to all the characters and I feel like even when you make mistakes the game doesn't lord them over your head too much. These ratings even without any specific improvement on them [aside from graphics] would've gotten a higher rating if the game was longer.   I SHOULD be giving this a YES vote because as a Graphic novel it does it's job but because I bought it as a game lover and not as a person wanting a story I expected both gameplay and story from it. Take this more as a warning than a NO. To me as a game player this game has no replay value, is only good for light gaming and is not worth it's price at full cost.

I'm writing this review before I've finished the game for a reason I'll outline in a moment.    SO FAR:  As a sum of it's part, the game is pretty great.  The game is rich with story, and the protagonist really carries the conflict which of course makes for a great interactive narrative.   This is my first forray into Tell Tale Games' unique story-telling, but the controls seem well-balanced and occasionally thrilling for a point-and-click.   The graphics are fitting, and the game is as well-directed a cinematic experience as I've encountered.   The English voice acting is mostly great, and my suspension of disbelief was maintained through the iffy bits by the other high points mentioned in this review.     THE REASON I WOULD NOT RECOMMEND
